title: Advanced Urdu 2
description: Islamic Studies

title: Urdu Poetry
description: Islamic Studies : Interpretation of Urdu poetry for students with intermediate to advanced-level knowledge of Urdu-Hindi language. Includes advanced grammar topics, cultural and historical background, and interpretation and analysis.
prerequesite: ISLA 552D1/D2 or permission of the instructor.

title: Special Topics 1
description: Islamic Studies : Selected topics in Islamic studies.

title: Special Topics 2
description: Islamic Studies : Selected topics in Islamic Studies.

title: Arab Women's Literature
description: Islamic Studies : Explorations of writings by Arab women. Issues include: translation/reception, gender and genre, categories of knowledge about Arab women, feminist and post-colonial theories/methodologies.

title: Anthropology and Iranian Studies
description: Islamic Studies : Advanced examination of research issues in the field of modern history and anthropology of Iran. Topics will include the social construction of knowledge, politics and society, cultural history and technology.

title: Islamic Philosophy & Theology
description: Islamic Studies : Advanced examination of research issues in the field of Islamic philosophy and theology. Topics will include dialectic, metaphysics, the commentary traditions and 19th century Kalâm.

title: Introductory: Research Materials - Islamic Studies
description: Islamic Studies : Exploration of research materials in Islamic Studies, including intellectual output of Islamic civilization, compositions, Arabic nomenclature, Arabic script and transliteration systems, published and unpublished materials (theses, manuscripts, books printed by lithography, facsimile editions, monographic, serial, e-publishing), websites, databases; major reference books (bibliographies, encyclopedias, handbooks, online/published catalogues, language/biographical dictionaries).

title: Introductory: Research Materials - Islamic Studies
description: Islamic Studies : Exploration of research materials in Islamic Studies, including intellectual output of Islamic civilization, compositions, Arabic nomenclature, Arabic script and transliteration systems, published and unpublished materials (theses, manuscripts, books printed by lithography, facsimile editions, monographic, serial, e-publishing), websites, databases; major reference books (bibliographies, encyclopedias, handbooks, online/published catalogues, language/biographical dictionaries).

title: Introductory: Research Materials - Islamic Studies
description: Islamic Studies : See ISLA 603D1 for course description.

title: Arabic Manuscript Tradition
description: Islamic Studies : This course will examine the way manuscript books were bound, transcribed, decorated, collated, corrected and glossed. It will deal with various scribal practices employed in the critical apparatus, including abbreviations, and will provide practical assistance on how to locate and choose a manuscript for text editing.

title: Persian Literature
description:
Islamic Studies : Advanced examination of research issues in the field of Persian literature.  Topics will include modern and medieval Persian poetry and prose; women in early Qajar Iran, 
c. 1795-1850.

title: Pre-Modern Islamic History
description: Islamic Studies : Advanced examination of research issues in the field of pre-modern Islamic history. Topics will include Shi'ite doctrine and law (fiqh), the Safivid Empire, and Shi'ites in Iran, Iraq and Lebanon.

title: Women in Contemporary Middle East
description: Islamic Studies : Advanced examination of research issues related to the experiences of women in the contemporary Middle East. Topics will include patriarchy, women and Islam, women and the state, nationalism and anti-colonialism struggles; labour, public space and theoretical issues.

title: Modern Middle Eastern History
description: Islamic Studies : Advanced examination of research issues in modern Middle East history.  Topics will include the history of Arab nationalism; the history of European Imperialism in the Middle East; the Middle East and historiography.

title: Modern Arabic Literature
description: Islamic Studies : Advanced examination of research issues in the field of Arabic literature. Topics will include women's literature, gender and nationalism in literature, language use in literature and the diasporic literatures of the Middle East.

title: Islamic Law
description: Islamic Studies : Advanced examination of research issues in the field of Islamic law. Topics will include modernity, gender, family law, and property.

title: Pro-Seminar: Ottoman Institutions
description: Islamic Studies

title: Special Topics 2
description: Islamic Studies : Selected topics in Islamic studies.

title: Islamic Politics in Africa
description: Islamic Studies : Advanced examination of research issues in the field of Islamic politics in Africa. Topics will include: Political Islam; social movement perspectives; Islam, state-building and civil conflict; the political economy of Islamist extremism, and globalization; informal markets and the rise of the politics of Identity.

title: History of Science in Islam
description: Islamic Studies : Advanced examination of research issues in the historiography of Islamic science. These include: the appropriation and naturalization of ancient Greek science by Islamic scientists; the Arabic-Latin translation movement and the influence of Islamic science on medieval and Renaissance Europe; and the question of the post-medieval decline of Islamic science.

title: Thesis Research 1
description: Islamic Studies : Six credits for accepted thesis proposal.

title: Thesis Research 2
description: Islamic Studies : Six credits on submission of completed thesis.

title: Thesis Research 3
description: Islamic Studies : Twelve credits for thesis passed by Internal and External examiners.

title: Comprehensive Examination
description: Islamic Studies : An examination that must be passed by all doctoral candidates in order to continue in the doctoral program.

title: Islamic Law
description: Islamic Studies : The nature of the law, its origins and historical development, the medieval schools of law, modern evolution of the law, and its roles in Islamic religious and political thought.

title: Islamic Law
description: Islamic Studies : See ISLA 706D1 for course description.

title: Qur'an Exegesis (Classical)
description: Islamic Studies : A study of two or three suras of the Qur'an as interpreted by classical exegetes. The suras considered will vary from year to year.

title: Problems in Shi'ah Thought
description: Islamic Studies : A history of Shi'i thought dealing with central texts, movements, and practices.

title: Islamic Legal Discourse
description: Islamic Studies : A study of the modes in which medieval Muslim jurists gave expression to their individual theories of law.

title: Islamic Developments - Modern India and Pakistan
description: Islamic Studies : Significant movements in Islamic thought and political action, since the Mughal downfall. The influence of Sirhindi; Waliyullah and his school; the Mujahidin; 1857, De'oband; Aligarh; Azad and Muslim participation in Indian nationalism; Iqbal; Pakistan. Pakistan constitutional and ideological issues; birth of Bangladesh and subsequent developments; Muslims in India since partition.

title: Islamic Developments - Modern India and Pakistan
description: Islamic Studies : See ISLA 723D1 for course description.

title: Islamic Logic
description: Islamic Studies : Advanced study of the history of Arabic syllogistic, dialectec and other forms of logical discourse.

title: Islamic Philosophy
description: Islamic Studies : Consideration of the development of philosophic thought among the Muslims. Classical Arabic or Persian writings will be used.

title: FYS: Italy's Literature in Context
description: Italian (Arts) : The purpose of this seminar is to re-visit, problematically, the commonsense notion that literature "reflects" reality (or society). Classics of twentieth-century Italian writing shall be analyzed as the response of that nation's literary imagination to the contradictions of its turbulent political and social history.

title: Italian for Beginners
description: Italian (Arts) : Grammar, reading, dictation. Intensive practice in speech patterns and written structures. Conversation and composition. Visual material and selected readings will be used in describing the making of contemporary Italy.

title: Italian for Beginners
description: Italian (Arts) : See ITAL 205D1 for course description.

title: Beginners Italian Intensive
description: Italian (Arts) : Designed to cover in one term the same material as ITAL 205D1/ITAL 205D2. The Summer term will also be given in Florence, Italy, as part of McGill's Summer Study in Italy program.
prof name: {'Fall': ['Anna maria Tumino'], 'Winter': ['Anna maria Tumino', 'Cristiana Furlan'], 'Summer': ['Cristiana Furlan', 'Marco Piana']}

title: Elementary Italian
description: Italian (Arts) : The course is intended for students who have never studied Italian but who have had some informal exposure to the language. Grammar, reading, conversation and composition. An outline of Italian civilization, oral presentations and discussions.

title: Elementary Italian
description: Italian (Arts) : See ITAL 210D1 for course description.

title: Intermediate Italian
description: Italian (Arts) : Direct continuation of ITAL 205D1/ITAL 205D2. Grammar, literary readings, conversation. Grammar exercises and composition. Reading of selected literary works, oral presentations and group discussion.

title: Intermediate Italian
description: Italian (Arts) : See ITAL 215D1 for course description.

title: Intermediate Italian Intensive
description: Italian (Arts) : Course designed to cover in one term the same material as ITAL 215D1/ITAL 215D2. Direct continuation of ITAL 206. The Summer term will be given in Florence, Italy, as part of McGill's Summer Study in Italy program.
prerequesite: ITAL 205D1/ITAL 205D2 or ITAL 206 or permission of the Department

title: Understanding Italy
description: Italian (Arts) : An introductory critical perspective on a series of issues (North/South, Church/State, the family, regionalism, Fascism) related to contemporary Italy through novels, films and essays.

title: Italian Literary Composition
description: Italian (Arts) : Analysis and discussion of selected 19th and 20th century literary texts with a view to improving language and composition skills. Review of major grammatical difficulties.

title: Advanced Reading and Composition
description: Italian (Arts) : Course is given in Florence, Italy, as part of McGill's Summer Study in Italy program. The understanding of grammatical structures through a variety of exercises; paraphrasing, translating, composition and discussion. Particular emphasis will be placed on syntax through the study of contemporary texts.

title: Reading Italian Literature
description: Italian (Arts) : A selection of poetic, narrative and theatrical texts from different historical periods, providing students with advanced tools in textual analysis and close reading of Italian literary texts.
prerequesite: ITAL 215 or ITAL 216 or permission of the instructor.

title: The Italian Short Story
description: Italian (Arts) : Introduction to the Italian "novella" tradition from Boccaccio (14th Century) to the present.

title: Manzoni: Novel and Nationhood
description: Italian (Arts) : An analysis of the historical novel "I promessi sposi", by Alessandro Manzoni: its political, social and intellectual role in the evolution of Italy towards nationhood (Risorgimento).

title: Masterpieces of Italian Literature 2
description: Italian (Arts) : A survey of Italian literature from Renaissance to the 20th century. Interdisciplinary approach.

title: Commedia Dell'Arte
description: Italian (Arts) : Playhouses, actors, stage techniques, masks and scenarios of the "Commedia dell'Arte".

title: Italian Cultural Studies
description: Italian (Arts) : A cultural studies approach to contemporary Italian society. Focus on distinctive traits of Italian popular culture through literature, film, television and other media.
prerequesite: ITAL 215D1/D2 or 216 or permission of instructor

title: Topics in Italian Culture
description: Italian (Arts) : Selected topics in Italian culture (topics may vary and may concentrate on one or more of the following areas: geography, history, music, art history, political science, and/or literature).

title: Perspectives on Italy
description: Italian (Arts) : Course is given in Florence, Italy, as part of McGill's Summer Study in Italy program. A study of various topics relating to the perception of Italy, the country, its people and their culture as seen by foreign and/or Italian writers. Course to be taught in English.

title: The Invention of Italian Literature
description: Italian (Arts) : The course presents Italian's major texts and authors over the ages, by critically exploring how the invention of Italian literature impacts the formation of a national identity.
prerequesite: ITAL250 or above, from amongst courses taught in Italian or permission of Department.

title: Italian Cinematic Tradition
description: Italian (Arts) : Italian films in original language. Films are examined from a wide historical and cultural perspective. Introduction to issues and preoccupations central to the Italian cultural tradition.
prerequesite: ITAL250 or above, from amongst courses taught in Italian or permission of Department.

title: Italian Theatrical Traditions
description: Italian (Arts) : An overview of the major works and genres of Italian theatre from the Renaissance to the present, analyzing their reception and influence on Italian society.
prerequesite: ITAL250 or above, from amongst courses taught in Italian or permission of Department.

title: The Art of Essay Writing
description: Italian (Arts) : Word formation in the Italian language. Syntactic and stylistic aspects of texts by Italian essayists.
prerequesite: ITAL 300 or permission of the Department

title: Romanticism in Italy
description: Italian (Arts) : The course introduces key figures in early-19th century Italian culture (Leopardi, Foscolo, Manzoni), and problematizes both the notion of Romanticism in Italy, and its relationship to the movement for Italian unification.
prerequesite: ITAL250 or above, from amongst courses taught in Italian or permission of Department.

title: Dante and the Middle Ages
description: Italian (Arts) : An introduction to the work of Dante Alighieri, a pillar of medieval European literature. The times in which he lived, the institutions and cultural shifts of that era, the influence exercised by Dante's work, as well as how it has been perceived in our time.

title: Medieval Discourses on Love
description: Italian (Arts) : Medieval ideas, attitudes and behaviour surrounding love as represented in literature: readings will include excerpts from early Italian love lyrics, Dante's Vita Nuova, Petrarch's Canzoniere, Boccaccio's Decameron.

title: Contemporary Italian Prose
description: Italian (Arts) : A study of Italian fiction, docu-fiction and non-fiction published since 1990, examined in the context of the debates on post-modernism.
prerequesite: ITAL 210D1/D2, ITAL 215D1/D2, ITAL 216, or permission of instructor

title: Modern Italian Literature
description: Italian (Arts) : Major prose works of Italian literature as they reflect the reactions of writers to the social, cultural and political dilemmas facing Italian society in the 20th century.

title: Post-World War 2 Literature and Society
description: Italian (Arts) : A study of Italian prose fiction and non-fiction in the context of some of the events and issues that marked these years: the aftermath of Fascism, the economic boom, terrorism, the Mafia, the North-South question.

title: Gender, Literature and Society
description: Italian (Arts) : Questions of gender identity and literary representation as they emerge from women's texts or from comparisons of women's and men's texts, in relation to specific social and historical conditions. May focus on any time period in Italian history, from medieval to contemporary.

title: The Italian Renaissance
description: Italian (Arts) : A presentation of the main ideas and literary masterpieces of the Italian Renaissance (13th-17thC), in the context of Italy's social, political, religious and cultural climate. Reading and discussion of selected literary texts and visual material.

title: Literature of the Renaissance
description: Italian (Arts) : Reading and discussion of selected literary texts (Poliziano, Lorenzo, Alberti, Sannazzaro, Castiglione among others) will provide an opportunity to become familiar with the social and political conditions of literary production, the ideas and debates about language and literature, and the literary genres which emerged during the Renaissance.

title: The Italian Baroque
description: Italian (Arts) : An analysis of the Italian Baroque period through an interdisciplinary overview of its major figures (Caravaggio, Bernini, Galileo, Marino, Vico) and cultural genres (commedia dellâ•Žarte, opera, still life)

title: Classics of Italian Cinema
description: Italian (Arts) : Key works in the history of Italian cinema; an in-depth analysis of a few exceptional works; emphasis on the complex web of relationship connecting each work to a wide range of cultural products and expressions, from literature to popular culture, in Italy and internationally.

title: Cinema and Society in Modern Italy
description: Italian (Arts) : A survey of the most important trends in post-war Italian cinema seen in the context of the rapidly and dramatically evolving society of modern Italy.

title: Italian Epic Poetry
description: Italian (Arts) : The evolution of the epic mode from its classical to romance expressions, with a special focus on Medieval and Renaissance Italian poetry.
prerequesite: ITAL250 or above, from amongst courses taught in Italian or permission of Department.

title: Italian Realisms
description: Italian (Arts) : Focus on pivotal narrative and cinematic works that illustrate the evolution of Italian realism from the middle ages to the contemporary period.

title: Women's Writing since 1880
description: Italian (Arts) : A study of Italian women writers and their search for literary identity.
prerequesite: any 300 level course given in Italian or permission of the Department

title: Italian Futurist Movement
description: Italian (Arts) : Futurism is essentially a multidisciplinary movement. Using textual and visual material, its various manifestations - in literature, "paraliterature", painting, photography, theatre, film, sculpture, architecture, music, dance, and performance - will be examined from a double perspective: the futurist theory/practice relationships on the one hand and, on the other, the multiple links between Italian futurism, the "historical" avant-garde outside Italy and the neo-avant garde movements of the 60s and 70s.

title: Interdisciplinary Seminar
description: Italian (Arts) : Interdisciplinary seminar on Italian studies.  Topic varies by year.

title: Italian Regional Identities
description: Italian (Arts) : The course explores tensions between national and regional narratives in Italy's literature, culture, language, and society.
prerequesite: ITAL250 or above, from amongst courses taught in Italian or permission of Department.

title: Italian Modernism
description: Italian (Arts) : A study of representative works of major Italian authors from the fin-de-siècle to WWII.

title: Pirandello
description: Italian (Arts) : Selected readings from Pirandello's essays, short stories, novels and plays in the light of his ideological rejection of the literature and society of his time.

title: The Twentieth Century
description: Italian (Arts) : Topics in twentieth-century Italian literary and cultural history. The focus may be on a movement, a theme, a genre, a specific writer, or a specific period.

title: Leopardi Poet and Philosopher
description: Italian (Arts) : The major early 19th century poets in the context of Italian and European Romanticism.

title: Petrarch and His Legacy
description: Italian (Arts) : A thorough reading of Petrarch's Canzoniere, letters and excerpts from his treatises, followed by a survey of their literary, philosophical and political legacies.
prerequesite: ITAL250 or above, from amongst courses taught in Italian or permission of Department.

title: Tasso's "Gerusalemme Liberata"
description: Italian (Arts) : A study of Tasso's poem in the context of the Counter Reformation.

title: Individual Reading Course
description: Italian (Arts) : In exceptional circumstances, this course may be used to meet special interests of students or to assist them in meeting the standard requirements of the Department.

title: Italy and the Visual Age
description: Italian (Arts) : A study of the emergence of a mass culture industry in the 19th and 20th centuries, through the survey of a variety of visual sources.
prerequesite: ITAL250 or above, from amongst courses taught in Italian or permission of Department.

title: Machiavelli
description: Italian (Arts) : Machiavelli, the political thinker and man of letters. A portrait of Machiavelli as political strategist, playwright and observer of his times. Reading of The Prince as well as selected plays, letters and other writings.

title: Religious Identities in Italy
description: Italian (Arts) : This course examines the role played by religion in shaping Italian identities by looking at the works of Dante, Marsilio Ficino, Giovanni Pico, Galileo Galilei and other Early Modern authors in their cultural and institutional contexts. By looking at how these authors expressed their beliefs and interacted with religious institutions, students are invited to critically engage on the concept of "religion".

title: Joint Honours Thesis
description: Italian (Arts) : Research and completion of the Honours thesis on an approved subject.

title: Honours Thesis
description: Italian (Arts) : Honours Thesis.

title: Honours Thesis
description: Italian (Arts) : See ITAL 471D1 for description.

title: Honours Thesis (Intensive)
description: Italian (Arts) : Intensive Honours thesis.

title: Italian Cinema and Video
description: Italian (Arts) : Different Italian film maker or videomaker every year, presenting a selection of his/her significant works. Discussions will include script analysis, interviews, articles and books by the director in focus, in addition to theoretical and critical statements by scholars. Established and new directors will be considered alternately.

title: Internship: Italian Studies
description: Italian (Arts) : Internship with an approved host institution or organization.
prerequesite: Permission of the departmental Internship Advisor.

title: History of Italian Language
description: Italian (Arts) : A historical survey of the intense debate on the problem of literary language in Italy, from Dante to the present time, as caused by the variance between spoken and literary languages; followed by an in-depth examination of the theoretical and literary texts of one particular period.

title: Boccaccio and the Italian Novella
description: Italian (Arts) : A study of Boccaccio's "Decameron" and of Italian narrative prose up to the 16th century.

title: Topics in 19th & 20th Century Literature
description: Italian (Arts) : Exploration of individual authors, genres, and literary or cultural movements that have marked Italian culture in the 19th and 20th century.

title: 13th-16th Century Literature
description: Italian (Arts) : Topics in the literature of the 13th to the 16th centuries.

title: Italian Literary Criticism
description: Italian (Arts) : From Croce's "critica estetica" to contemporary semiology. Critical essays will be analyzed and compared with theoretical statements about the definition and role of literature.

title: The Literary Tradition
description: Italian (Arts) : The course highlights the importance of tradition in literature and focuses on different aspects of Italian literary history.

title: The Literary Tradition
description: Italian (Arts) : The course highlights the importance of tradition in literature and focuses on different aspects of Italian literary history.

title: Individual Reading Course 1
description: Italian (Arts) : Supervised readings supervised by a member of staff.  Topics will be chosen to suit individual interests.

title: Individual Reading Course 2
description: Italian (Arts) : Supervised readings supervised by a member of staff.  Topics will be chosen to suit individual interests.

title: Bibliography of Italian Literature
description: Italian (Arts) : Tools for literary research: encyclopedias, dictionaries, bibliographies, journals, Internet sites, library catalogues. Tools for linguistic research: historical, specialized, Italian-dialect, etymological vocabularies. History of the book: manuscript, early printing, catalogues of incunabula and of early books.

title: Bibliography of Italian Literature
description: Italian (Arts) : Tools for literary research: encyclopedias, dictionaries, bibliographies, journals, Internet sites, library catalogues. Tools for linguistic research: historical, specialized, Italian-dialect, etymological vocabularies. History of the book: manuscript, early printing, catalogues of incunabula and of early books.

title: Bibliography of Italian Literature
description: Italian (Arts) : See ITAL 610D1 for course description.

title: Topics in Literary Theory
description: Italian (Arts) : An introduction to some of the main subjects and authors of modern literary theory. Topics may include reception theory, deconstruction, postmodernism, cultural studies, formalism and structuralism, semiotics, gender studies, psychoanalysis, Marxism, translation and subjectivity.

title: Italian Humanism
description: Italian (Arts) : An examination of Italian humanism as a historiographical category and as an aspect of Italian culture.

title: Italian Literature and Western Cultural Tradition
description: Italian (Arts) : A study of certain aspects of Italian literature in relation to the literatures of other Western countries.

title: Topics in Italian Cinema
description: Italian (Arts) : Italian cinema in conjunction with issues of cultural theory.

description: Italian (Arts) : Presentation and discussion of research work.

title: Comprehensive Examination
description: Italian (Arts) : An examination that must be passed by all doctoral candidates in order to continue in the doctoral program.

title: Topics in Italian Literature 1
description: Italian (Arts) : Review of selected topics in Italian literature.

title: Topics in Italian Literature 2
description: Italian (Arts) : Review of selected topics in Italian literature.

title: Student Staff Seminar
description: Italian (Arts) : This seminar is intended to provide graduate students the opportunity to present their research to the members of the department, obtain feedback and re-present their progress at the end of the term.

title: Ph.D. Language Requirement
description: Italian (Arts) : See "Ph.D Language Tests" and consult the department.

title: FYS: Images - Jewish Identities
description: Jewish Studies : A seminar devoted to literary portrayals of Jews by Jews and non-Jews from Biblical times to the present. Both positive and negative understandings of Jewish identity and Judaism will be studied.

title: Jewish Law
description: Jewish Studies : The nature and history of Jewish law; literary and legal sources; selections in English from the Mishnah and Talmud, as well as selected post-Talmudic Texts, on such subjects as Contracts, Torts, Public Law and Family Law.

title: Introduction to Jewish Music
description: Jewish Studies : A survey of Jewish music from the Bible to the present. Special attention is given to the Jewish and non-Jewish contexts in which the music developed.

title: Introduction to Jewish Literature
description: Jewish Studies : A survey of Jewish literary texts from the Bible to the present day including selections from psalms, prophecy, prayer, poetry, short stories and novels. Critical literature on these texts reflecting comparative, religious, historical, feminist, psychoanalytic and linguistic approaches will also be studied.

title: Introduction to Yiddish Literature
description: Jewish Studies : A survey of Yiddish literature with a particular focus on the modern period (the 1860s to the present). As we read major works of Yiddish literature, we will discuss the main factors in its development, including its position as a minority literature, Ashkenazi civilization’s religious foundations and multilingualism, the rise of political movements, and the trauma of the Holocaust. In his Nobel lecture, Yiddish writer Isaac Bashevis Singer described Yiddish as “the idiom of the frightened and hopeful humanity.” We will explore both the reasons behind and the effects of such universalization of Yiddish language, literature, and culture.

title: Jewish Studies 1: Biblical Period
description: Jewish Studies : The history, literature and beliefs of Judaism's formative period. Both Biblical and non-Biblical materials will be studied. The Bible in the context of cognate literatures of the Ancient Near East; non-Biblical documents will be analysed for their bearing on the Jewish tradition.

title: Jewish Studies 2: 400 B.C.E. - 1000
description: Jewish Studies : The history, literature and intellectual developments in Judaism during late antiquity. Special emphasis will be placed on rabbinic literature e.g. Babylonian Talmud, Palestinian Talmud, the midrashim both as literary works and for the light they shed on the events and ideologies of the period.

title: Jewish Studies 3: 1000 - 2000
description: Jewish Studies : The Jewish experience from the rise of the European centres to the present.

title: Introductory Hebrew
description: Jewish Studies : Language acquisition - introductory Hebrew.

title: Introductory Hebrew
description: Jewish Studies : Language acquisition - introductory Hebrew.

title: Introductory Hebrew
description: Jewish Studies : See JWST 220D1 for course description.

title: Literature and Society
description: Jewish Studies : A panoramic analysis of Israeli society through poetry, fiction, essays, interviews and testimonial narratives reflecting the country's historical, ideological and ethnic complexity. In English translation, we will read Oz, Amichai, Habibi, Har-Even and Yehoshua, as well as new authors from divergent ethnic, religious and ideological positions.

title: Contemporary Israeli Fiction
description: Jewish Studies : Study of selected themes in literary works by Israeli authors.

title: The Holocaust
description: Jewish Studies : Consideration of the history of the Holocaust and the literary, theological and cultural responses to the destruction of European Jewry.

title: Interdisciplinary Lectures
description: Jewish Studies : Interdisciplinary lectures in Jewish studies.  Topic varies by year.

title: The Jewish Holy Days
description: Jewish Studies : An exploration of the Jewish holy days. Emphasis is placed on their historical development, philosophical messages, and ritual forms.

title: History of Jewish Philosophy & Thought
description: Jewish Studies : An introduction to Jewish philosophy and thought from the Hellenistic period (Philo) to the beginning of the modern era (Spinoza) focusing on topics such as prophecy and philosophy, God and the world; the Law as a canon of ethical rules and as a political constitution. Survey of the treatment of such issues by Jewish thinkers from Philo to Maimonides.

title: Modern Jewish Philosophy
description: Jewish Studies : A survey of Jewish philosophical responses to the challenges of the modern world. Jewish thinkers studied include Baruch Spinoza, Moses Mendelssohn, Hermann Cohen, Martin Buber, Franz Rosenzweig, Joseph Soloveitchik and Emil Fackenheim.

title: Introductory Yiddish 1
description: Jewish Studies : An introduction to Yiddish, the millennium-old language of Ashkenazic Jews. This course will cover basic grammar and vocabulary and will include practice in speaking, reading, and writing. The course materials draw on Yiddish literature, humor, songs, and films, and will thus allow students to combine the acquisition of practical language skills with an exploration of Yiddish culture—from its beginnings in medieval Germany through its past and present in Central and Eastern Europe, the Americas, Israel, and all over the world.

title: Introductory Yiddish 2
description: Jewish Studies : This course is designed for students with a basic command of Yiddish who wish to improve their knowledge of the language and to further explore the culture behind it. Further development of the four language skills - speaking, reading, writing, and listening - with a particular emphasis on expanding vocabulary and improving grammar. Basic overview of the main Yiddish dialects. Course materials include selections from Yiddish literature, humor, songs, and films of Jewish life past and present.

title: Charisma and Social Change
description: Jewish Studies : An introduction to charismatic phenomena in politics, religion and the media, and interpretation of them, from the ancient prophets to the modern period. Particular attention will be given to charisma as a general force for social change and also the lives of individuals such as Lenin, Krishnamurti and Chaplin.

title: The Soviet Jewish Experience
description: Jewish Studies : Sovietization both fueled the modernization of Russian Jewry and contributed to its eventual suppression. This experience will be examined from two perspectives: history and literature. The interrelationship between culture and politics and the effects of ideology and censorship on literature will be discussed.

title: American Jewish History / Colonial Era to WWI
description: Jewish Studies : The interaction of Jewish and American historical traditions in forging the American Jewish experience. The themes of acculturation, immigration and political behaviour will be treated.

title: The American Jewish Community
description: Jewish Studies : Issues affecting American Jewry in the post-World War I era until today and the American Jewish community's responses to those issues. Special emphasis on understanding the community responses and reactions to developments in both the American society and in the Jewish world.

title: Jews in Film
description: Jewish Studies : An introduction to the portrayal of Jews in film from the 1920s to the present. Films to be studied will usually be based on literary texts in English, which will form part of the required study. Films in languages other than English will be subtitled.

title: Believers, Heretics and Critics
description: Jewish Studies : Issues in the development of Biblical interpretation based on classical Jewish thought, heretical Jewish doctrines and contemporary Biblical criticism.

title: Denominations in North American Judaism
description: Jewish Studies : A survey of Reform, Reconstructionist, Conservative and Orthodox Judaism in North America. Emphasis is placed on the ideology forwarded by the movements since their inception.

title: Modern Liberal Jewish Thought
description: Jewish Studies : The work of Mordecai Kaplan, followed by a study of several contemporary authors following feminist, mystical and postmodernist tendencies.

title: Social and Ethical Issues Jewish Law 1
description: Jewish Studies : A brief introduction to the nature and history of Jewish law. Topics include: redemption of hostages; abortion; death and dying.

title: Judaism and the Occult
description: Jewish Studies : A study of Judaism and the Occult.

title: Intermediate Hebrew
description: Jewish Studies : This course is designed to integrate students at various levels into one group with the aim of improving their basic language skills and preparing them for advanced Hebrew.

title: Intermediate Hebrew
description: Jewish Studies : This course is designed to integrate students at various levels into one group with the aim of improving their basic language skills and preparing them for advanced Hebrew.

title: Intermediate Hebrew
description: Jewish Studies : See JWST 320D1 for course description.

title: The Israeli Novel
description: Jewish Studies : In-depth examination of selected Israeli novels written during the past fifty years of national formation and consolidation. Authors may include Agnon, Yehoshua, Oz, Shabtai, Shalev and others.

title: Israeli Literature in Translation
description: Jewish Studies : Survey of contemporary Israeli fiction that reflects Israel's cultural, political, and historical concerns. Authors may include Yehoshua, Oz, Librecht, Michael, Shamir, Castel-Bloom, and others.

title: A Book of the Bible
description: Jewish Studies : One book of the Bible will be studied in its entirety in Hebrew. Emphasis on the contributions of Ancient Near Eastern Studies (archaeology, comparative literature and Semitic linguistics) to understanding the text.

title: A Book of the Bible
description: Jewish Studies : One book of the Bible will be studied in its entirety in Hebrew. Emphasis on the contributions of Ancient Near Eastern Studies (archaeology, comparative literature and Semitic linguistics) to understanding the text.

title: A Book of the Bible
description: Jewish Studies : One book of the Bible will be studied in its entirety in Hebrew. Emphasis on the contributions of Ancient Near Eastern Studies (archaeology, comparative literature and Semitic linguistics) to understanding the text.

title: A Book of the Bible
description: Jewish Studies : One book of the Bible will be studied in its entirety in Hebrew. Emphasis on the contributions of Ancient Near Eastern Studies (archaeology, comparative literature and Semitic linguistics) to understanding the text.

title: The Hebrew Liturgy
description: Jewish Studies : The structure, contents, foci and ideological assumptions of Jewish prayer. Texts will reflect the different approaches to prayer in Biblical, rabbinic, medieval and modern periods, with emphasis on the evolution of the classical Hebrew prayer book (Siddur) and the Passover Haggadah.

title: Jews and Muslims: A Modern History
description: Jewish Studies : This course examines the modern history of Jewish-Muslim relations beyond just conflict. We will look at the experience of Jews and Muslims -- as individuals and communities -- who charted new cultural territory while navigating colonialism, nationalism, war, and decolonization, through close readings of a wide variety of primary sources (including letters, memoirs, fiction, music, film, and photography) and historical scholarship.

title: Jewish Philosophy and Thought 1
description: Jewish Studies : Focuses on either a period, a current of thought or the work of a thinker in the history of Jewish thought from Antiquity to the Middle Ages, paying particular attention to the relationship of Jewish thinkers to intellectual trends in their respective cultural contexts. Contemporary Muslim and Christian theologians and philosophers.

title: Jewish Philosophy and Thought 2
description: Jewish Studies : Focuses on either a period, a current of thought or the work of a thinker in the history of Jewish thought from the Middle Ages to Modern Times, paying particular attention to the relationship of Jewish thinkers to intellectual trends in their respective cultural contexts. themes and concerns of Jewish theology and on Jewish responses to contemporary trends in European thought.

title: Advanced Hebrew
description: Jewish Studies : Language acquisition - advanced Hebrew.

title: Advanced Hebrew
description: Jewish Studies : Language acquisition - advanced Hebrew.
prerequesite: JWST 200 or JWST 320 or permission of the Hebrew Language Coordinator

title: Advanced Hebrew
description: Jewish Studies : See JWST 340D1 for course description.

title: Introduction to Rabbinic Literature
description: Jewish Studies : An introduction to the study of Rabbinic texts.

title: Modern Jewish Studies
description: Jewish Studies : Topics in Jewish Studies. Semesters will be devoted to specific issues and periods of the Jewish Experience since 1500 and the literature produced by Jews during this period.

title: Modern Jewish Studies
description: Jewish Studies : Topics in Jewish Studies. Semesters will be devoted to specific issues and periods of the Jewish Experience since 1500 and the literature produced by Jews during this period.

title: Modern Jewish Studies
description: Jewish Studies : Topics in Jewish Studies. Semesters will be devoted to specific issues and periods of the Jewish Experience since 1500 and the literature produced by Jews during this period.

title: Modern Jewish Studies
description: Jewish Studies : Topics in Jewish Studies. Semesters will be devoted to specific issues and periods of the Jewish Experience since 1500 and the literature produced by Jews during this period.

title: Studies in Modern Jewish Literature
description: Jewish Studies : Within a comparative framework, this course examines cultural, thematic and artistic developments in the works of modern Jewish literature written in both Jewish and non-Jewish languages.  For those without reading knowledge of the original, all works are available in English translation.

title: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Jewish Studies 1
description: Jewish Studies : A study of a topic in Jewish studies from the vantage point of multiple disciplines. For example, "the Figure of Moses in 20th Century Jewish Thought, Literature, Music and Psychoanalysis." Topic varies by year.

title: Interdisciplinary Lectures 2
description: Jewish Studies : Interdisciplinary lectures in Jewish studies.  Topic varies by year.

title: The Yiddish Canon
description: Jewish Studies : This course will focus on the Classical Period (1860 - 1915) in Yiddish literature. We will be reading landmark texts in English translation.

title: Jewish Labour Movement/Eastern Europe
description: Jewish Studies : The development of the Jewish labor and socialist movement in Eastern Europe from the last quarter of the 19th century to the Bolshevik Revolution.

title: Jewish Labour Movement/North America
description: Jewish Studies : The development of the Jewish labor and socialist movement in North America from the last quarter of the 19th century to WWI.

title: Topics in Jewish Philosophy 1
description: Jewish Studies : Topics in Jewish philosophy. Topic varies by year.

title: Topics in Jewish Philosophy 2
description: Jewish Studies : Topics in Jewish philosophy.  Topic varies by year.

title: The Shtetl: 1500-1897
description: Jewish Studies : Using historical, sociological, literary and cultural sources, this course will examine various aspects of communal and individual life in the shtetl, the Jewish - or largely Jewish - town in Eastern Europe.

title: Modern Jewish Ideologies
description: Jewish Studies : The rise and development of the various ideologies which attempt to define the Jews in historical, national and socio-cultural terms will be analyzed within the context of modern European nationalism. Selected texts of the Jewish Enlightenment, Science of Judaism, Peretz Smolenskin, Leon Pinsker, Simon Dubnow, Chaim Zhitlowsky and Ahad Ha-Am.

title: History of Zionism
description: Jewish Studies : An examination of the development of the Zionist idea, the most influential expression of modern Jewish nationalism, which led to the creation of the Jewish state. The transformation of elements of traditional Jewish messianism into a modern political ideology. Hibbat Zion, Political Zionism, Cultural and Synthetic Zionism will be discussed.

title: Hebrew Language and Israeli Culture 1
description: Jewish Studies : A post-advanced study of Hebrew language through an encounter with Israeli film, music and art as well as academic, journalistic, literary, and dramatic texts (all materials are in Hebrew).

title: Hebrew Language and Israeli Culture 2
description: Jewish Studies : A post-advanced study of Hebrew language through an encounter with Israeli film, music and art as well as academic, journalistic, literary, and dramatic texts (all materials are in Hebrew).

title: Hebrew Language and Israeli Culture 3
description: Jewish Studies : A post-advanced study of Hebrew language through an encounter with Israeli film, music and art as well as academic, journalistic, literary, and dramatic texts (all materials are in Hebrew).

title: Hebrew Language and Israeli Culture 4
description: Jewish Studies : A post-advanced study of Hebrew language through an encounter with Israeli film, music and art as well as academic, journalistic, literary, and dramatic texts (all materials are in Hebrew).

title: Jews and the Modern City
description: Jewish Studies : In the forefront of the development of modern society in Europe and North America, the Jews have shown a distinct preference for the metropolis. The influence of Vienna and New York on the socio-cultural development of the Jews and on the Jewish contribution to general culture. The contributions of Schnitzler, Freud, Herzl and the New York intellectuals.

title: Jews and the Modern City
description: Jewish Studies : See JWST 371D1 for course description.

title: Topics in Jewish Music 1
description: Jewish Studies : A study of one style, historical period, or geographical location of Jewish musical expression.

title: Topics in Jewish Music 2
description: Jewish Studies : This course is the continuation of the study of one style, historical period, or geographical location of Jewish musical expression.

title: God and Devil in Modern Yiddish Literature
description: Jewish Studies : An exploration of some of the central themes in Yiddish literature: religious faith and doubt; the nature of good and evil; and the role of fear - both awe of the divine and terror of the demonic. We will discuss Yiddish writers’ use of East European Jewish folklore, the influence of Christian culture, as well as the effects of secularization, mass emigration, and the Holocaust. Readings will include works by major Yiddish writers of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, including I. L. Peretz, Sholem Aleichem, and Isaac Bashevis Singer.

title: Jews, Judaism and Social Justice
description: Jewish Studies : A study of North American Jewish activists, thinkers and organizations whose social justice work is deeply rooted in Jewish text and in the lessons of Jewish historical experience.

title: Holocaust Literature
description: Jewish Studies : Readings from Holocaust literature in English translation. Writers include Primo Levi, Aharon Appelfeld, Elie Wiesel, Dan Pagis, Paul Celan, Nelly Sachs, U.Z. Greenberg and others.

title: Yiddish: Intermediate 1
description: Jewish Studies : Intermediate study of standard Yiddish with emphasis on reading, composition and conversation. Knowledge of Yiddish culture will also be expanded.

title: Yiddish: Intermediate 2
description: Jewish Studies : Intermediate study of standard Yiddish with emphasis on reading, composition and conversation. Knowledge of Yiddish culture will also be expanded.

title: American Jewish Literature
description: Jewish Studies : An intensive study of American Jewish novels from the 1900s to the present. Attention to representations of gender, class and Jewishness as seen in relation to changing notions of America. Focus on ways novels represent and wrestle with Jewish difference.

title: Modern Jewish Authors
description: Jewish Studies : Introduction to representative novels written in America by Jews from the 1950s to the present. Issues of Jewish identity, ethnicity will inform our discussions. Focus on contemporary Jewish authors; consideration of the ways in which the complexities of American life are re-scripted in these novels.

title: Contemporary Hebrew Literature
description: Jewish Studies : Israeli literature in its original language with emphasis on in-depth literary analysis. Texts read in Hebrew; assignments may be written in English.

title: Literary Response to Loss/Separation
description: Jewish Studies : Discussion of loss in Jewish literature, particularly in Holocaust writings, and in various themes, in memories, dreams or in mysticism, for example. A basic introduction to clinical studies on grief will serve as background.
prerequesite: Some prior related university course at 300 level or higher, e.g. literature, psychology or social work. Permission of instructor required

title: Tutorial in Hebrew Literature
description: Jewish Studies : Individualized guided research on an approved topic in Hebrew literature.

title: The Poetry of Nationalism
description: Jewish Studies : An introduction to the work of various modern 'national poets'  - i.e. poets closely linked to national movements who expressed (or constructed) a particular national identity and whose work has lasting artistic value. These will include Mickiewicz of Poland, Tagore of India, Yeats of Ireland, and Bialik of pre-state Israel.

title: Maimonides' Mishneh Torah
description: Jewish Studies : Study of the Moses Maimonides' Mishneh Torah, including such subjects as idolatry, repentance, and sacrifices, to torts, contracts, and public law.

title: The Responsa Literature
description: Jewish Studies : The responsa, the judicial opinions of leaning rabbinic scholars from the medieval period to the present time. Particularly, the interaction between law and social, economic, political or cultural change.

title: Advanced Yiddish 1
description: Jewish Studies : Development of advanced Yiddish language skills in conversation and discussion, composition, and oral presentation. Particular emphasis will be placed on the reading and paraphrasing of a variety of literary texts.
prerequesite: JWST 380 or permission of the instructor

title: Advanced Yiddish 2
description: Jewish Studies : Additional development of advanced Yiddish language skills in conversation and discussion, composition, and oral presentation. Particular emphasis will be placed on the reading and paraphrasing of a variety of literary texts.
prerequesite: JWST 380D1 and JWST 380D2; or permission of the instructor.

title: Tutorial in Yiddish Literature
description: Jewish Studies : Individualized guided research on an approved topic in Yiddish literature.

title: Tutorial in Yiddish Literature
description: Jewish Studies : Individualized guided research on an approved topic in Yiddish literature.

title: Tutorial in Yiddish Literature
description: Jewish Studies : Indivisualized guided research on an approved topic in Yiddish literature.

title: Tutorial in Yiddish Literature
description: Jewish Studies : Individualized guided research on an approved topic in Yiddish literature.

title: Honours Thesis 1
description: Jewish Studies : A tutorial for the preparation of an Honours Thesis.

title: Honours Thesis 2
description: Jewish Studies : A tutorial for the preparation of an Honours Thesis.

title: Internship: Jewish Studies
description: Jewish Studies : Internship with an approved host institution or organization.

title: Directed Readings 1
description: Jewish Studies : Preserving advanced concentration in one area of Jewish Studies, with exposure to two others (including biblical interpretation, history, literature and Jewish thought/philosophy), this course will be tailored to the individual program requirements of our graduate students in close consultation with their supervisors and program director.

title: Directed Readings 2
description: Jewish Studies : Preserving advanced concentration in one area of Jewish Studies, with exposure to two others (including biblical interpretation, history, literature and Jewish thought/philosophy), this course will be tailored to the individual program requirements of our graduate students in close consultation with their supervisors and program director.

title: Directed Readings 3
description: Jewish Studies : Preserving advanced concentration in one area of Jewish Studies, with exposure to two others (including biblical interpretation, history, literature and Jewish thought/philosophy), this course will be tailored to the individual program requirements of our graduate students in close consultation with their supervisors and program director.

title: Directed Readings 4
description: Jewish Studies : Preserving advanced concentration in one area of Jewish Studies, with exposure to two others (including biblical interpretation, history, literature and Jewish thought/philosophy), this course will be tailored to the individual program requirements of our graduate students in close consultation with their supervisors and program director.

title: Seminar in Jewish Thought
description:
Jewish Studies : Examination of a theme or philosopher in the history of Jewish thought with particular attention to the intersections between Jewish thought
and other intellectual traditions (e.g. Greek, Islamic, Christian, etc.)

title: Jewish Bible Interpretation 1
description: Jewish Studies : The issues, approaches, and texts of Jewish Bible interpretation between the Biblical and Talmudic eras: Bible interpretation in the Bible; in Greco-Roman Jewish literature; in the Mishnah, Tosefta, Targumim, and Talmudim; early Samaritan interpretation, Bible interpretation in ancient synagogue art, and in the massoretic literature.

title: Jewish Bible Interpretation 2
description: Jewish Studies : The issues, problems, approaches, and texts of Jewish Bible interpretation in medieval, renaissance, early modern, and modern times. Interpretation in the Geonic, Ashkenazi, Sefardic, North African, Italian, European, Yemenite, North American and Israeli centres of Jewish Learning.

title: Bible Interpretation in Antiquity
description: Jewish Studies : Studies in bible interpretation in Antiquity.

title: Topics in Yiddish Literature
description: Jewish Studies : Supervised research in Yiddish literature. Work will focus on one genre, literary school or author.

title: Early Rabbinic Parshanut 1
description: Jewish Studies : Advanced level work on one aspect of Jewish Bible interpretation in late antiquity.

title: Medieval Ashkenazi Parshanut
description: Jewish Studies : Issues, techniques and texts of Jewish Bible study in medieval France and Germany; Rashi, Qara, Rashbam, the Tosafists, etc.

title: Abraham Ibn Ezra as Parshan
description: Jewish Studies : A study of the Bible commentaries of lbn Ezra.

title: Maimonides as Parshan
description: Jewish Studies : Biblical Interpretation in the Guide of the Perplexed and related writings.

title: Innovative Medieval Parshanut
description: Jewish Studies : The dynamics of Jewish Bible interpretation in medieval times and the attempts by various authors to read the Bible as an independent Hebrew document, not only in the light of the pre-medieval rabbinical exegetical tradition.

title: Medieval Parshanut
description: Jewish Studies : Advanced level work in one aspect of Jewish Bible interpretation in medieval times.

title: Judaism and Poverty
description: Jewish Studies : An introduction to the subject of poverty in Jewish literature and its influence on religions such as Christianity and Islam, and on modern, secular ideologies, especially socialism, and creative literature.
prerequesite: One course in Jewish Studies, Sociology or Social Work.

title: Modern Jewish Biblical Scholarship
description: Jewish Studies : The past two centuries have witnessed the active participation of many Jewish writers in the academic enterprise of Bible scholarship. This course will explore the writings of a selection of European, American, and Israeli writers and the roles they have played in archaeological, philological, historical, literary and other critical endeavours.

title: Topics: Modern Jewish Thought
description: Jewish Studies : Studies of topics in Modern Jewish thought.  Topic varies by year.

title: Medieval Islamic and Jewish Philosophy
description: Jewish Studies : Deals with the manifold points of contact between medieval Muslim and Jewish intellectual history. Muslim and Jewish philosophers, theologians and mystics belonged to the same currents of thought, used the same language and studied the same sources in translation, proposing similar answers to questions that arose in the context of their respective religious traditions.
prerequesite: one course in Greek, Islamic or Jewish Philosophy, or permission of instructor.

title: Biblical Literature
description: Jewish Studies : A study of biblical literature.

title: History of Hebrew Bible Text
description: Jewish Studies : The text of the Hebrew Bible as it evolved between antiquity and the most recent printed edition. Attention will be given to the accurate reconstruction of the Bible from primary and secondary witnesses: Greek and Aramic translations, Dead Sea Scrolls, and ancient quotations, and the Massoretic notes and lists.

title: Topics in Parshanut
description: Jewish Studies : Advanced level work in one aspect of Jewish Bible Interpretation that cuts across all periods of Jewish Bible interpretation.

title: Jewish Family Law
description: Jewish Studies : Study of the complex interaction between Jewish law and both Canadian and American law in the area of marriage and divorce.

title: Aramaic Language
description: Jewish Studies : A study of the Aramaic language.

title: Tutorial: Eastern European Studies 1
description: Jewish Studies : Individualized guided research on an approved topic in East European studies.

title: Tutorial: Eastern European Studies 2
description: Jewish Studies : Indivisualized guided research on an approved topec in East European studies.

title: Tutorial in Yiddish Literature
description: Jewish Studies : Individualized guided research on an approved topic in Yiddish literature.

title: Tutorial in Yiddish Literature
description: Jewish Studies : Individualized guided research on an approved topic in Yiddish literature.

title: Directed Readings 5
description: Jewish Studies : Preserving advanced concentration in one area of Jewish Studies, with exposure to two others (including biblical interpretation, history, literature and Jewish thought/philosophy), this course will be tailored to the individual program requirements of our graduate students in close consultation with their supervisors and program director.

title: Directed Readings 6
description: Jewish Studies : Preserving advanced concentration in one area of Jewish Studies, with exposure to two others (including biblical interpretation, history, literature and Jewish thought/philosophy), this course will be tailored to the individual program requirements of our graduate students in close consultation with their supervisors and program director.

title: East European Jewish History 1
description: Jewish Studies : (1500 - 1800) Studies on specific issues and problems related to the social and cultural history of the Jews in Eastern Europe.

title: Topics: In Jewish Thought
description: Jewish Studies : Tutorial in Jewish thought.

title: Literary Analysis of Hebrew Fiction
description: Jewish Studies : A methodological examination of contemporary Hebrew narratives with particular attention to literary structures and narrative form.

title: M.A. Thesis 1
description: Jewish Studies : Normally done during the first semester of residence, this project entails original bibliographic research related to the history of Jewish Bible interpretation, usually the preparation of an extensive bibliography of one writer, text or theme. The choice may relate to the thesis topic.

title: M.A. Thesis 1
description: Jewish Studies : Normally done during the first semester of residence, this project entails original bibliographic research related to the history of Jewish Bible interpretation, usually the preparation of an extensive bibliography of one writer, text or theme. The choice may relate to the thesis topic.

title: M.A. Thesis 1
description: Jewish Studies : See JWST 690D1 for course description.

The choice may relate to the thesis topic.

title: M.A. Thesis 1
description: Jewish Studies : See JWST 690N1 for course description.

title: M.A. Thesis 2
description: Jewish Studies : A study of the history of Jewish interpretation of one verse, based on 100 primary sources of a topical analysis of a major issue in the history of Jewish Bible interpretation.

title: M.A. Thesis 3
description: Jewish Studies : Preparation of the thesis.

title: M.A. Thesis 4

description: Jewish Studies : Bibliography and preparation of a research proposal.

title: M.A. Thesis 2
description: Jewish Studies : Thesis preparation and ongoing presentation of research results.

title: M.A. Thesis 3
description: Jewish Studies : Writing and submission of thesis.

title: Research in Jewish Studies
description: Jewish Studies : Practical problems and resources related to research and key theoretical debates in the field will be discussed.

title: Comprehensive Examination
description: Jewish Studies : An examination that must be passed by all doctoral candidates in order to continue in the doctoral program.

title: Comprehensive Examination
description: Jewish Studies : An examination that must be passed by all doctoral candidates in order to continue in the doctoral program.

title: Comprehensive Examination
description: Jewish Studies : See JWST 791D1 for course description.

title: Research Seminar: Latin America and the Caribbean
description: Latin American & Caribbean St : An interdisciplinary research seminar on topics of common interest to staff and students of the Latin-American and Caribbean Studies Program.
department: Inst for the St of Development

title: Honours Thesis
description: Latin American & Caribbean St : This course is designed to allow students to pursue interdisciplinary research projects under close supervision.
department: Inst for the St of Development
prerequesite: LACS 497 and permission of the Program Adviser

title: Internship: Latin America & Caribbean Studies
description: Latin American & Caribbean St : Internship with an approved host institution or organization.
department: Inst for the St of Development
prerequesite: Permission of the program Internship Advisor.

title: Contractual Obligations
description: Law General : Basic concepts of contractual obligation in the Civil and Common Law. Formation and consent; formalities; cause and consideration; relativity of contracts and privity; lesion and unconscionability; performance and breach; frustration and force majeure; contractual remedies.

title: Contractual Obligations
description: Law General : See LAWG 100D1 for course description.

title: Extra-Contractual Obligations/Torts
description: Law General : Integrated study of basic concepts of extracontractual obligations in the Civil and Common law. Fault and other bases for liability; protected interests; causation; reasons for exoneration; apportionment of liability; intersection of human rights and civil wrongs.

title: Extra-Contractual Obligations/Torts
description: Law General : See LAWG 101D1 for course description.

title: Criminal Justice
description: Law General : Basis, nature and functioning of criminal justice within and across legal orders, with a focus on Canadian criminal justice. Main determinants of crime and rationales for criminalizing certain conduct. Key substantive, procedural, evidentiary and sentencing aspects of the criminal law, and the social impact of criminal justice.
prof name: {'Fall': ['Frederic Jean Megret', 'Marie Manikis', 'Alexandre Bien-Aimé', 'Mairi Leigh M Springate']}

title: Criminal Justice
description: Law General : Basis, nature and functioning of criminal justice within and across legal orders, with a focus on Canadian criminal justice. Main determinants of crime and rationales for criminalizing certain conduct. Key substantive, procedural, evidentiary and sentencing aspects of the criminal law, and the social impact of criminal justice.
prof name: {'Winter': ['Frederic Jean Megret', 'Marie Manikis', 'Alexandre Bien-Aimé', 'Mairi Leigh M Springate']}

title: Integration Workshop
description: Law General : An introduction to law and legal studies that complements the other first-year courses using transversal and integrative approaches.
prof name: {'Fall': ['Mark Walters', 'Kirsten Anker', 'Karen Sloan', 'Kun Fan', 'Evan Fox-Decent', 'Pierre-Emmanuel Moyse', 'Johanne Poirier', 'Colleen Sheppard', 'Helge Dedek', 'François Crépeau', 'Stamatia Piper', 'Cristina Toteda']}

title: Integration Workshop
description: Law General : An introduction to law and legal studies that complements the other first-year courses using transversal and integrative approaches.
prof name: {'Winter': ['Mark Walters', 'Kirsten Anker', 'Karen Sloan', 'Kun Fan', 'Evan Fox-Decent', 'Pierre-Emmanuel Moyse', 'Johanne Poirier', 'Colleen Sheppard', 'Stamatia Piper', 'Cristina Toteda', 'Helge Dedek', 'Robert Leckey']}

title: Commercial Law
description: Law General : The contract of sale in the Civil Law and Common Law traditions; nature and scope of the contract of sale; conditions of formation; sale of property of another; obligations of the seller, including delivery, quality, title; obligations of the buyer, transfer of title; product liability; comparative reference made to American U.C.C. rules and U.N. Convention on the International Sale of Goods.

title: Legal Ethics and Professionalism
description: Law General : The course provides an overview of the ethical principles and rules that are relevant to one’s life as an expert in the law, including ethical requirements for the practice of law in Canada and abroad. The course is taught over the course of weekly meetings during the term, in addition to an intensive period during Focus Week.
prerequesite: PRAC 147D1/D2 or equivalent (transfer & advance standing students only).

title: Property
description: Law General : Integrated study of the foundations, principles and mechanisms of property law. Examination of common law, civil law and indigenous traditions in respect of property. Key relationships in respect of things and services as well as limitations on property rights.

title: Property
description: Law General : Integrated study of the foundations, principles and mechanisms of property law. Examination of common law, civil law and indigenous traditions in respect of property. Key relationships in respect of things and services as well as limitations on property rights.

title: Family Law
description: Law General : Study of conjugality and other close personal relationships as understood by law; parent-child relationships; dissolution of conjugal relationships; support rights at the end of close personal relationships.

title: Family Property Law
description: Law General : Administration of and entitelment to wealth in conjugal and other close personal relationships, in common and civil law, with consideration of other legal traditions. Management and distribution of family resources through matrimonial regimes, marriage and domestic contracts, household mandates, common law trusts, legislative division of family assets, liberalities, social practice.
prerequesite: PRV1 144 or PRV4 144 or permission of instructor.

title: Private International Law
description: Law General : The function, nature and sources of Private International Law in the common law and civil law traditions. Conflicts of laws; general operation of conflict rules (application of foreign law, substitution of laws of forum). Conflicts of jurisdiction and recognition of foreign judgments. Harmonization and unification of laws.

title: Secured Transactions
description: Law General : Main incidents of law and suretyship and the law of real security in the common and civil traditions; security on land and commodities; nature of suretyship and effects of a contract among the creditor, debtor, surety and co-sureties; classifications and types of preferences, priorities and real security.

title: Secured Transactions
description: Law General : Main incidents of law and suretyship and the law of real security in the common and civil traditions; security on land and commodities; nature of suretyship and effects of a contract among the creditor, debtor, surety and co-sureties; classifications and types of preferences, priorities and real security.

title: Secured Transactions
description: Law General : See LAWG 400D1 for course description.

title: Evidence (Civil Matters)
description: Law General : Basic principles of evidence as applied and developed in the context of the civil process in all jurisdictions in Canada. Topics include: burden and standard of proof; relevance; the different kinds of evidence, i.e. documentary evidence; testimonial evidence (lay and opinion evidence), presumptions, admissions and real evidence; the principal rules of admissibility, including the hearsay rule and its exceptions.

title: Evidence (Criminal Matters)
description: Law General : An introduction to principles of evidence with a focus on admissibility in criminal matters. Topics include relevance, hearsay, opinion, character, similar facts, confessions and illegally-obtained evidence. The course begins with a discussion of burdens and standards of proof.

title: Complex Legal Transactions 1
description: Law General : In-depth case studies of complex legal transactions, to allow students to learn how areas of law interact in a sophisticated, practical environment, and to permit them to develop their analytical and research skills. Transactions may include land development schemes, national and international issues of securities and complex non-commercial transactions.

title: Sustainable Development
description: Law General : Foundations of sustainable development as a justice claim instantiated in law and policy. Topics of investigation include: theoretical (in)coherence; institutional architecture; principles of international and domestic law; the integration of social,economic and environmental goods; inter-generational justice, precaution and uncertainty; adoption in soft law.

title: Inter-American Human Rights
description: Law General : History and development of the Inter-American System, with a focus on the Inter-American Commission of Human Rights and Inter-American Court of Human Rights. Examination of their constitutive statutes. Survey of the mechanisms for redress provided by the Commission and the Court.

title: Death and Property
description: Law General : An exploration, from a transsystemic perspective, of legal approaches to the transfer of property on death. Topics covered include: wills; estate administration; testamentary intention and its intersection with public order; survivorship; testamentary interpretation; intestacy; and family obligations and entitlements upon death, as these concepts arise within different legal traditions.

title: Critical Engagements with Human Rights
description: Law General : This seminar examines the connections between the theory and practice of human rights. It explores theoretical, ethical and strategic issues related to human rights discourse, advocacy and activism, and critically examines fact finding, monitoring and reporting, litigation, grass roots mobilization and media engagement in advancing human rights.

title: Advanced Civil Law Property
description: Law General : This course aims develop civil law reasoning and methodology through the study of certain concepts and constructs in civil law property.This course provides an opportunity for immersion in the culture, epistemology and practices of the Civil Law Tradition

title: Critical Race Theory Advanced Seminar
description: Law General : This course will explore the evolving contours of a theoretical approach to law that has developed both a substantive challenge to legal liberalism and critical legal studies, as well as an alternative literary style built on the use of narrative.

description: Law General : An intensive study of a particular topic in public or private law.

title: Law Focus Week Workshop 1
description: Law General : The course is taught in an intensive period during Focus Week, and offers an opportunity to critically analyze and develop relevant skills for experts in the law, such as negotiation, mediation, project management, community mobilization, policy analysis, empirical research, entrepreneurship, financial analysis, and the like.

title: Law Focus Week Workshop 2
description: Law General : The course is taught in an intensive period during Focus Week, and offers an opportunity to critically analyze and develop relevant skills for experts in the law, such as negotiation, mediation, project management, community mobilization, policy analysis, empirical research, entrepreneurship, financial analysis, and the like.

description: Law General : The course is taught in an intensive period during Focus Week, and offers an opportunity to critically analyze and develop relevant skills for experts in the law, such as negotiation, mediation, project management, community mobilization, policy analysis, empirical research, entrepreneurship, financial analysis, and the like.

title: Law Innovation
description: Law General : This course provides an introduction to the concept of innovation, its role in the economy, the institutions that foster or hinder it, the laws that promote or undermine it, and its historical, psychological and social context. Through a combination of interactive lectures students will explore the complexity of the subject and its connections with law, the economy, history, sciences and technology and government and firm policies. In addition, through small group projects, students will deploy and extend their knowledge by applying it to a particular proposed innovation.

title: Innovation for Non-Law Students
description: Law General : This course provides an introduction to the concept of innovation, its role in the economy, the institutions that foster or hinder it, the laws that promote or undermine it, and its historical, psychological and social context. Through a combination of interactive lectures students will explore the complexity of the subject and its connections with law, the economy, history, sciences and technology and government and firm policies. In addition, through small group projects, students will deploy and extend their knowledge by applying it to a particular proposed innovation.

title: Communication 1
description: Law General : Key writing strategies for graduate students in Law.

title: Communication 2
description: Law General : Key writing strategies for graduate students in Law.

title: Legal Education Seminar
description: Law General : A review of the aims, objectives, methods and techniques of legal education, including design and execution of the curriculum; an inquiry into law's ontology and legal epistemology; an examination of practical issues (attending graduate school, selecting a supervisor, types of legal research and employment as a law teacher).

title: Interdisciplinary Seminar in European Studies
description: Law General : Interdisciplinary seminar on a theme relevant to the study of Europe.

title: Comprehensive Exam - Law
description: Law General : An examination that must be passed by all doctoral candidates in order to continue in the doctoral program.

title: Legal Research Methodology for DCL
description: Law General : Instruction in legal scholarship and research methodology, including proposal development and electronic legal research geared towards DCL students.

title: Literature Review, Analysis and Proposal
description: Law General : Submission of final subject, methodology and bibliography to committee for feedback. Prepare Analysis of literature (approx. 15,000 words covering theory, methodology, literature review/critical analysis, and gap(s) in the literature). To be completed by the end of the first year (DCL 2) of the DCL program.

title: DCL Research Seminar 1
description: Law General : Develop theoretical perspectives and orientation of thesis. Written and oral presentation of DCL thesis research by the DCL candidate to the candidate’s supervisor, thesis advisory committee and other interested individuals. Must be completed by end of second year (DCL 3).

title: DCL Research Seminar 2
description: Law General : Students need to demonstrate significant development of their research project, including development of theoretical perspectives and orientation of thesis. Written and oral presentation of DCL thesis research by the DCL candidate to the candidate’s supervisor, thesis advisory committee and other interested individuals. Must be completed by 4th year (DCL 5).

title: Labour Law
description: Labour/Employmt/Environmt Law : An introduction to Canadian labour law including collective bargaining, arbitration and industrial relations generally. Emphasis on the Canada Labour Code, the Quebec Labour Code and related statutes.

title: Employment Law
description: Labour/Employmt/Environmt Law : Survey of the employment contract including hiring practices, dismissals, duties of the employer and the employee including loyalty, non-competition, impact of statutes (Labour Standards Act, Charter of the French Language, etc...) and recourses. The purpose of the course is to deal with non-collective agreement employment contracts, which govern most of the working population.

title: Law and Poverty
description: Labour/Employmt/Environmt Law : The differential character of the law concerning rich and poor as reflected in case studies in criminal law, consumer law, housing law, welfare law. The "delivery systems" available for legal  services to the poor and alternative organizational models for legal services; the role of law schools, government and the professional bar.

title: Introduction to Liberal Arts
description: LIBA : An introduction to the compass and significance of a Liberal Arts education, focusing on contemporary developments and challenges in the humanities.  It considers the contribution of a range of disciplines and approaches across a wide range of linguistic traditions, geographical areas and time periods and pays particular attention to the global dimension of contemporary humanistic culture.

title: Individual Reading Course
description: LIBA : Individual reading course in any topic pertinent to Liberal Arts as approved by the Director of the Liberal Arts program.

title: Seminar in Liberal Arts
description: LIBA : Readings and discussions on liberal arts.

title: Honours Thesis
description: LIBA : Under the direction of a supervisor, students research and complete an honours thesis on an approved subject in Liberal Arts.

title: First Year Seminar: Language and Mind
description: Linguistics : This fast paced course introduces students to challenges faced by scientists who study how language is represented in the human brain.

title: Introduction to the Study of Language
description: Linguistics : General interest course; intended for students in all fields. Topics include: linguistic competence vs. performance, language and the brain, language acquisition, sociolinguistics, historical linguistics, language universals, pragmatics.

title: Introduction to Linguistics
