description: Psychiatry : Supervised reading and discussion of selected issues and topics in contemporary psychiatry. Students will be responsible for assigned readings and for preparation of a graded paper.

title: Cultural Psychiatry
description: Psychiatry : Topics covered: cross-national epidemiological and ethnographic research of major and minor psychiatric disorders; culture-bound syndromes and idioms of distress; culture, emotion and social interaction; psychological and symbolic healing; mental health of immigrants and refugees; psychiatric theory and practice as cultural constructions; methods of cross-cultural research.

title: Cultural Psychiatry
description: Psychiatry : Topics covered: cross-national epidemiological and ethnographic research of major and minor psychiatric disorders; culture-bound syndromes and idioms of distress; culture, emotion and social interaction; psychological and symbolic healing; mental health of immigrants and refugees; psychiatric theory and practice as cultural constructions; methods of cross-cultural cross-cultural research.

title: Cultural Psychiatry
description: Psychiatry : See PSYT 711D1 for course description.

title: Psychiatric Epidemiology
description: Psychiatry : An overview of the applications of epidemiology in psychiatry, including instruments and methods used in community studies; major recent population surveys of psychiatric disorders; study of treatment-seeking, pathways to care and use of services; interaction between psychological distress and physical health; methods used in specific populations; evaluation of treatment.
prerequesite: EPIB 601 or equivalent, or permission of instructor.

title: Land Use Planning
description: Public Law 1 : A comparative study of private and public control of land use and development, involving master plans, zoning bylaws, subdivision control, urban re-development, expropriation, and regional planning.

title: Constitutional Law
description: Public Law 2 : A comprehensive treatment of the theory, law and practice of the constitution, including legislative, executive and judicial institutions in Canada. The rule of law in executive government and in the lawmaking process. Parliamentary sovereignty, constitutional amendment, and the federal system, including the division of legislative powers. Guarantees of fundamental freedoms with emphasis on the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.

title: Constitutional Law
description: Public Law 2 : See PUB2 101D1 for course description.

title: Constitutional Law of the United States
description: Public Law 2 : An introduction to constitutional law in the United States, including an examination of the role of the Supreme Court, the separation of legislative, executive and judicial powers, federalism, fundamental rights, freedom of expression and religion, equal protection and the state action doctrine.

title: Public International Law
description: Public Law 2 : The traditional fields of International Law including nature and sources; recognition, territory and acquisition of territory; jurisdiction on the high seas; nationality; diplomatic and consular privileges and immunities; responsibility of states; interpretation of treaties; legal control of force and aspects of the U.N. Charter, special Canadian problems of international law.

title: Criminal Law
description: Public Law 2 : The exploration of major problems in criminal law and its administration; emphasis on basic concepts which govern the implementation of the Criminal Code in Canada.

title: Taxation
description: Public Law 2 : The general principles of Canadian income tax law. The emphasis is on federal, personal and corporation tax with some reference to Quebec income tax law.

title: Taxation
description: Public Law 2 : The general principles of Canadian income tax law. The emphasis is on federal, personal and corporation tax with some reference to Quebec income tax law.

title: Taxation
description: Public Law 2 : See PUB2 313D1 for course description.

title: The Administrative Process
description: Public Law 2 : The administrative process and the legal structure of administrative agencies. Statutory interpretation, delegated legislation, policy rules, administrative discretion, administrative procedures and problems of institutional design will be considered in the context of some contemporary administrative agencies.

title: Judicial Review of Administrative Action
description: Public Law 2 : The control of administrative decision-makers. Problems of delegation, formal jurisdiction, natural justice and errors of fact and law. Judicial review remedies; appeals; reconsideration; tort and contractual liability of administrative agencies; privative clauses; public inquiries; ombudsman schemes.

title: Judicial Review of Administrative Action
description: Public Law 2 : The control of administrative decision-makers. Problems of delegation, formal jurisdiction, natural justice and errors of fact and law. Judicial review remedies; appeals; reconsideration; tort and contractual liability of administrative agencies; privative clauses; public inquiries; ombudsman schemes.

title: Judicial Review of Administrative Action
description: Public Law 2 : See PUB2 401D1 for course description.

title: Municipal Law
description: Public Law 2 : Municipal institutions in the Province of Quebec and their constitution and powers. Judicial review of the acts of municipal authorities and officers in the general context of administrative law. Judicial nullity and other problems. Municipal taxation. Civil responsibility.

title: Trial Advocacy
description: Public Law 2 : The basic techniques of examination and cross-examination of witnesses in the context of a series of simulated trials. The emphasis is on active participation and on practical exercises in the basic problem areas: the unfolding of the narrative; the use of suggestive questions and the aide-mémoire; cross-examination and contradiction with prior written and oral statements; the production of exhibits and documentary proof. The framework is primarily one of criminal and statutory law, where these techniques are much more tightly defined.

title: Criminal Procedure
description: Public Law 2 : Principles of the law of criminal procedure. An examination of the criminal process from the point of suspicion to trial and appeal. The relationship to the process of the legal rights contained in the Charter of Rights and Freedoms will be examined.

title: Law and Psychiatry
description: Public Law 2 : The roles of lawyers and psychiatrists in the handling of the mentally ill within the legal process. Consideration of the civil commitment and criminal commitment processes, insanity and "automatism" defences, the psychiatrist as expert witness, mental illness as a problem in relation to legal capacity. Some sessions will be conducted jointly with members of the psychiatric profession.

title: Advanced Criminal Law
description: Public Law 2 : Specific crimes and defenses, and problems in procedure, as a continuation of Criminal Law and Criminal Procedure. Selected topics will be announced in advance.

title: International Criminal Law
description: Public Law 2 : Crimes against the law of nations, war crimes (the Nuremberg trials, the Eichmann case), genocide and the way in which states co-operate to fight organized crime, terrorism, hijacking, etc. Topics include: jurisdiction (crimes committed in foreign countries, at sea, in aircraft, extradition, international judicial assistance) and the recognition and enforcement of foreign criminal sentences.

title: Comparative Federalism
description: Public Law 2 : Institutional design of federal states, or of supra-national arrangements, in comparative perspective. Rationale for federal constitutions; confederal vs. federal organization; symmetric vs. asymmetric federations; allocation of powers; the subsidiarity principle; accession to and secession from the federation; the place of popular sovereignty; federalism within central legislative or executive institutions.

title: Sentencing in Canadian Law
description: Public Law 2 : Survey of principles of sentencing and correctional law in Canada. This course reviews general principles such as aims of punishment, matters of procedures and evidence, and review of sentences by appellate courts. A detailed examination of selected topics include participation of victims in sentencing, dangerous offenders, native offenders, homicide cases.

title: Statutory Interpretation
description: Public Law 2 : Legislation as a legal instrument, its various classifications, purposes and forms, styles of legislative drafting, codification, the process of interpretation, the interpretation of statutes and codes and rules of construction.

title: The Law of International Organization
description: Public Law 2 : Legal aspects of institutionalized multilateral diplomacy. Comparative study of the constitutional instruments of international organizations in the UN system and their law-making functions. Legal issues of international civil service.

title: Tax Policy
description: Public Law 2 : Public aspects of tax legislation; federal-provincial agreements; tax sharing and equalization; municipal aspects; social problems in tax policy. Negative tax and re-distribution of resources.

title: Corporate Taxation
description: Public Law 2 : In-depth consideration of problems unique to corporations and their shareholders including the small business deduction and refundable taxes; distributions to shareholders; corporate  reorganizations and liquidations; the capital gain and rollover.

title: Immigration and Refugee Law
description: Public Law 2 : A study of Canadian and Quebec immigration and refugee law, practice and policy, with particular exploration of the historical development-and contemporary paradox-of border regulation; interface with national security, employment policy and trade theory; admissions categories and the construction of illegality; impact of Charter and international human rights law.

title: Foundations
description: Public Law 3 : Overview of the spirit, history, and sources of Civil and Common Law traditions in their Canadian manifestations; introduction to Aboriginal legal traditions. The course explores issues of legal history and institutions, relationship between private and public law, comparative methodology, legal theory and ethics.
prof name: {'Fall': ['Ronald Niezen', 'Daniel Weinstock', 'Mark Antaki'], 'Winter': ['Ronald Niezen', 'Daniel Weinstock', 'Mark Antaki']}

title: Foundations
description: Public Law 3 : Overview of the spirit, history, and sources of Civil and Common Law traditions in their Canadian manifestations; introduction to  Aboriginal legal traditions. The course explores issues of legal history and institutions, relationship between private and public law, comparative  methodology, legal theory and ethics.

title: Foundations
description: Public Law 3 : See PUB3 116D1 for course description.

title: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
description: Public Law 3 : A critical analysis of the Charter and its implications for the legal process in general, and domestic human rights law in particular, organized around the following themes: pre-Charter human rights law and its legacy; general considerations respecting the entrenchment, application and interpretation of the Charter; procedural issues and judicial review under the Charter; advocacy under the Charter.

title: Introduction to the Study of Quebec
description: Quebec Studies : This course is an introduction to the ideas and approaches that scholars have used and developed to study Quebec. It will familiarize students with some of the foremost issues which have shaped Quebec historically and continue to influence contemporary life. Employing an interdisciplinary focus, QCST 200 examines changing notions about territory, identity, language, citizenship and belonging. The complexity and diversity of Quebec (11 Aboriginal nations, multilingual, multiethnic and religious communities, minority status within Canada and much more) will also be explored from a comparative perspective to identify characteristics that Quebec shares with other nations and those that are different.

title: Quebec Culture and Society
description: Quebec Studies : A multidisciplinary course that looks at Quebec with an aim of integrating key social, economic, cultural, political and historical aspects.

title: Quebec Studies Summer Seminar
description: Quebec Studies : This intensive course, mainly in French, introduces non-Quebec students to Quebec and Montreal's history and culture. Special emphasis on French-language skills. Students attend lectures and seminars by instructors and invited experts. Weekend cultural activities will reinforce course themes.
prerequesite: Intermediate level placement test required or permission of the instructor.

title: Contemporary Issues in Quebec
description: Quebec Studies : A multidisciplinary seminar that looks at a theme or topic concerning Quebec Society with the goal of integrating key social, economical, cultural, political and historic aspects.
prerequesite: QCST 300 or permission of the instructor

title: Tutorial/Travaux dirigés
description: Quebec Studies : Sous la direction du Directeur du Programme d'études sur le Québec ou d'un professeur, l'étudiant(e) choisit un sujet sur lequel il (elle) travaille pendant une année et rédige un essai d'une cinquantaine de pages. Under the supervision of either the Director of Quebec Studies Program or a professor, the student chooses a topic on which she/he works for a year and then submits an essay of approximately 50 pages.

title: Tutorial/Travaux dirigés
description: Quebec Studies : See QCST 472D1 for course description.

title: Foundations of Quantitative Life Sciences
description: QLSC : Provides an overview of important problems in the life sciences and introduces students to the latest computational, mathematical, and statistical approaches involved in their solution. Includes a survey of modern technologies for biological data acquisition and promotes a common language to communicate across the biological, physical, mathematical, and computational sciences. Topics will include bioinformatics and computational genomics, nonlinear dynamics in biological systems, linear and nonlinear models of biological signals, biophysical imaging technology, emergent behaviour in biophysical networks, and ecosystem dynamics and modeling.
prerequesite: BIOL 200 or BIOL 201; COMP 206, COMP 250, MATH 314; MATH 223 or MATH 236; MATH 323 or MATH 324
prof name: {'Fall': ['Erik Cook', 'Celia M T Greenwood', 'Ken Dewar', 'Frederic Guichard', 'Mathieu Blanchette', 'Jacek Majewski', 'Guillaume Bourque', 'Simon Gravel']}

title: Foundations of Quantitative Life Sciences
description: QLSC : Provides an overview of important problems in the life sciences and introduces students to the latest computational, mathematical, and statistical approaches involved in their solution. Includes a survey of modern technologies for biological data acquisition and promotes a common language to communicate across the biological, physical, mathematical, and computational sciences. Topics will include bioinformatics and computational genomics, nonlinear dynamics in biological systems, linear and nonlinear models of biological signals, biophysical imaging technology, emergent behaviour in biophysical networks, and ecosystem dynamics and modeling.
prerequesite: BIOL 200 or BIOL 201; COMP 206, COMP 250, MATH 314; MATH 223 or MATH 236; MATH 323 or MATH 324 QLSC 600D1
prof name: {'Winter': ['Erik Cook', 'Peter H Grutter', 'Paul Wiseman', 'Paul Francois', 'Anmar Khadra', 'Judith Mandl']}

title: Quantitative Life Sciences Seminars 1
description: QLSC : QLS Monthly Seminar Series and Journal Club.

title: Quantitative Life Sciences Seminars 1
description: QLSC : QLS Monthly Seminar Series and Journal Club.

title: Quantitative Life Sciences Seminars 1
description: QLSC : QLS Monthly Seminar Series and Journal Club.

title: Quantitative Life Sciences Seminars 1
description: QLSC : QLS Monthly Seminar Series and Journal Club.

title: Ph.D. Comprehensive Exam
description: QLSC : Compulsory comprehensive examination to evaluate the students' ability to carry out, present, discuss and defend research in their field of interest. The examination must be completed within the first 18 months of enrollment in the program.

title: TCP Radiology
description: Radiology (Diagnostic) : This one-week course will introduce students to imaging of the common and important conditions of the chest, abdomen, musculoskeletal and neurological systems as well as pediatric-related pathologies. Through small group session and clinical apprenticeship sessions with technologists, residents and radiologists, students better understand how medical images are acquired in each modality and how they are interpreted by the radiologist.

title: Undergraduate Research Project
description: Redpath Museum : Independent research project with a final written report.
prof name: {'Fall': ['Virginie Millien', 'Hans Carl Larsson', 'David M Green', 'Anthony Ricciardi', 'Rowan Barrett'], 'Winter': ['Hans Carl Larsson', 'David M Green', 'Anthony Ricciardi', 'Rowan Barrett', 'Virginie Millien'], 'Summer': ['Hans Carl Larsson']}

title: Science Writing
description: Redpath Museum : Techniques for effective science writing, including elements of reader-based scientific manuscripts and Abstracts. Emphasis on how to edit texts to make them logical, precise, and clear.
prerequesite: Completion of U1 and permission of the instructor.

title: Science and Museums
description: Redpath Museum : Natural history museums and their collections, how collections are created and maintained and how collections are used in scientific research. Context of natural history museums, collections-based research and curatorial methods.
prerequesite: A 200- or 300-level course that deals with diversity of specimens or objects relevant to Museum-based research and collections. e.g. BIOL 215, BIOL 305, EPSC 210, EPSC 233, ANTH 208, ANTH 310, PLNT 358, WILD 212, WILD 313, or permission of instructor.

title: Natural History of East Africa
description: Redpath Museum : Integrated study of African landforms, geologic history, climate, environments, biota, water resources and human influences, fostering a thorough understanding of the East African landscape and its inhabitants. Lectures, discussions on selected topics, use of museum resources and field studies will develop powers of observation, identification and enquiry.

title: Writing Research Articles
description: Redpath Museum : Students will learn about the scientific article, publishing in the sciences, and the benefits of writing for a wide audience. This course focuses on how to structure the Abstract, as well as the Introduction and Discussion section of the full manuscript, and on editing techniques.

title: Advanced Museum-Based Science
description: Redpath Museum : The course will allow senior undergraduates and graduate students to become intimately acquainted with key primary literature in museum-based science and the major issues challenging the field. Course components will include the weekly Redpath seminar series, and also a 2-hour weekly lecture, presentation, and discussion session.

title: Writing Science Articles 1
description: Redpath Museum : Principles and techniques for clear scientific writing with an emphasis on how to transform complex ideas into direct and precise ones by explaining research to peers and writing for interdisciplinary audiences.

title: Writing Science Articles 2
description: Redpath Museum : Skills for writing and publishing scientific articles, including peer-reviewed manuscripts and short, critical reviews of published articles. Topics include techniques for developing logical arguments and writing publishable manuscripts.

title: Religions of the Ancient Near East
description: Religious Studies : Introduction to the religions of Mesopotamia, Egypt and Syria-Palestine (excluding Israelite religion) from the fourth to first millennium B.C.E. Themes that will be discussed include: gods and goddesses, divine kingship, deification of kings, temple cult, death and afterlife, magic, piety, oracles, prayer, lament, myth and epic.

title: Religion of Ancient Israel
description: Religious Studies : An examination of the religion of Ancient Israel by a study of selected texts (narratives, laws, prophetic sayings, wisdom traditions, and psalms) from the Hebrew Scriptures/Old Testament in translation.

title: Bible and Western Culture
description: Religious Studies : To provide students of the humanities with knowledge of the Bible as a tool for interpreting religious references in Western literature, art and music. Biblical stories (e.g. Creation, Exodus), key figures (e.g. David, Job, Mary), and common motifs (e.g. Holy City, Pilgrimage, Bride) are explored, then illustrated by later cultural forms.

title: Judaism, Christianity and Islam
description: Religious Studies : An introduction to the beliefs, practices, and religious institutions of these three world religions.

title: Introduction to the Study of Religions
description: Religious Studies : This course is an introduction to classic and contemporary approaches to the academic study of religions. This includes perspectives from philosophy, theology, anthropology, sociology, psychology, phenomenology, and feminism. Students are also exposed to applications of these perspectives from visiting scholars who treat some aspect of a religious tradition in light of current-day interests and events. The primary objective is to introduce students to the principal theories and methods that have shaped our understanding of religion, its various meanings as well as its roles and functions in society.

title: World Religions and Cultures They Create
description: Religious Studies : The course explores multiple links between a wide range of religions and the cultural landscapes that nourish them and are shaped by them. It does so through a voyage across time that explores the mutual entanglements of selected religions and cultures originating and thriving in varied regional contexts, including Montreal. Course goals include highlighting the significance of religions for everyday culture, rituals of the body, religious responses to the environment as well as artistic expression and literary cultivation.

title: Jesus of Nazareth
description: Religious Studies : A critical study of selected ancient and modern accounts of the aims and person of Jesus. Attention will be given also to the question of the historical sources and to the relationship between faith and history.

title: Hinduism and Buddhism
description: Religious Studies : The interaction of Hinduism and Buddhism in India with special reference to the law of Karma, caste, women, ritual, death, yoga, and liberation. Determination of interpretative principles for understanding the religious psychology of Hindus and Buddhists.

title: Religions of East Asia
description: Religious Studies : This course introduces East Asia's major religions comparatively by addressing the continuous exchange of ideas and practices between traditions. Rather than adopting a mere chronological approach, Buddhism, Daoism, and Confucianism will be discussed thematically, taking in to account topics such as gender constructs, the secular and the sacred, material culture, and the apparent contrast between doctrine and practice.

title: Introduction to Sikhism
description: Religious Studies : An introduction to the historical and religious context in which the Sikh religion developed, its principal doctrines, practices and institutions and its evolution from its origins to the present, both inside and outside India.

title: Women in Judaism and Islam
description: Religious Studies : The role of women in Judaism and Islam from the point of view of institutionalized religious traditions and of women's religious subjectivity; how women's spiritual and social roles within their religious traditions are shaped by Revealed Law, Holy Text and the Authority of Interpretation. Comparative sociology of religion approach.

title: Introductory Sanskrit
description: Religious Studies : To develop basic language and reading skills.

title: Introductory Sanskrit
description: Religious Studies : See RELG 257D1 for course description.

title: Introductory Tibetan 1
description: Religious Studies : An introduction to the language of Classical Tibetan, specifically Tibetan script and basic grammar.

title: Introductory Tibetan 2
description: Religious Studies : A continuation of the introduction to the language of Classical Tibetan, specifically Tibetan script and basic grammar.

title: Introductory Tamil 1
description: Religious Studies : An introduction to the basic grammar and syntax of Tamil, a classical and modern language from South India. Students will acquire basic skills in reading, writing and speaking Tamil.

title: Introductory Tamil 2
description: Religious Studies : Advanced basic grammar and syntax of Tamil, a classical and modern language from South India. Students will acquire basic skills in reading, writing and speaking Tamil.

title: Religious Ethics and the Environment
description: Religious Studies : Environmental potential of various religious traditions and secular perspectives, including animal rights, ecofeminism, and deep ecology.

title: Sexual Ethics
description: Religious Studies : A study of the social construction of sexual identity and of selected issues regarding sexual behaviour.

title: Elementary New Testament Greek
description: Religious Studies : An introduction to the grammar and syntax of New Testament Greek.

title: Elementary New Testament Greek
description: Religious Studies : An introduction to the grammar and syntax of New Testament Greek.

title: Elementary New Testament Greek
description: Religious Studies : See RELG 280D1 for course description.

title: The Gnostic Worldview
description: Religious Studies : On the basis of newly-discovered gnostic writings, forms of gnosticism will be studied in their relationship to Platonists, Jewish and Christian circles in the Graeco-Roman world. Attention to Manicheism, Mandeism and some medieval and modern representatives of the gnostic worldview.

title: Introduction to Sikhism
description: Religious Studies

title: Second Temple Judaism
description: Religious Studies : A survey of Jewish history and thought from Ezra to the Mishnah; religious developments and groups, e.g., apocalypticism, Hellenistic Judaism, Essenes, Pharisees, Early Christianity and Rabbinic Judaism; and Biblical Interpretation in the Dead Sea Scrolls, Philo, Paul, Mishnah and Midrashim.

title: Literature of Ancient Israel 1
description: Religious Studies : An introduction to the literature of Ancient Israel in English translation. Reading and interpreting representative selections.

title: Literature of Ancient Israel 2
description: Religious Studies : Approaches to historical-critical scholarship and to the historical background of the Old Testament. Part of the course will be an examination of methods of biblical analysis through the use of learning cells.

title: Bible, Quran & Interpretations
description: Religious Studies : Jewish, Christian and Muslim scriptures as responses to earlier sacred texts and in the light of post-scriptural interpretations. The debates, polemics, interpretative strategies, and intellectual and spiritual sharing produced by these three religions in accepting, explaining, amplifying, modifying, and selectively rejecting their and other sacred scriptures.

title: Ancient Bible Translations
description: Religious Studies : Canonical changes, literary alterations, translation techniques, hermeneutical strategies, variant readings, and textual histories of the books of the Hebrew Bible as evidenced in the ancient versions, primarily the Septuagint. (No knowledge of Greek or Hebrew is required.)

title: New Testament Studies 1
description: Religious Studies : An introduction to the interpretation of the New Testament.

title: New Testament Studies 2
description: Religious Studies : An introduction to the critical study of the Gospels.

title: Topics in Biblical Studies 1
description: Religious Studies : Topics in biblical studies.  Topic varies by year.

title: Topics in Biblical Studies 2
description: Religious Studies : Topics of current interest in or between world religions.

title: Special Topics in Religion 1
description: Religious Studies : Topics of current interest in or between world religions.

title: New Religious Movements
description: Religious Studies : A critical analysis of the origins, character and influence of one or more religious movements of the 19th C. and beyond, with special attention to their religious principles and social function.

title: Special Topics in Religion 2
description: Religious Studies : Topics of current interest in, or between, world religions.

title: Special Topics in Religion 3
description: Religious Studies : Topics of current interest in, or between, world religions.

title: Special Topics in Religion 4
description: Religious Studies : Topics of current interest in, or between, world religions.

title: Western Intellectual Tradition
description: Religious Studies : Introduces essential sources in western philosophy and theology; examines the interdependence of these disciplines in their historical development; exposes students to the means and methods of argumentation that will allow them to compare and contrast these sources, and to develop and defend their own positions with respect to them.
prerequesite: U0 students must obtain permission from instructor

title: The Church in History 1
description: Religious Studies : A survey of major developments in the history of Christianity from the end of the apostolic age to 1500. Selected readings from primary and secondary sources will be used.

title: The Church in History 2
description: Religious Studies : Significant events and persons in the history of western Christianity from 1500 - 1948 will be studied. Attention is focused on mainline denominations in Britain and continental Europe.

title: Armenian Apostolic Tradition
description: Religious Studies : History of the Armenian Orthodox Apostolic Church from its foundation to the present: apostolic beginnings; St. Gregory the Illuminator and the establishment of Christianity in Armenia in the fourth century; development of doctrine, ecumenical discussions; theology, mystical thought, liturgy, sacred art and architecture.

title: Varieties Religious Experience in Christianity
description: Religious Studies : A survey of varieties of religious experience in Christianity.

title: Ancient Christian Church AD54 - AD604
description: Religious Studies : Significant persons and events from Nero's reign to the papacy of Gregory I. Attention to major Christian centres within the Roman Empire before Constantine, to the development of the Eastern Byzantine Church, and to the growth of the papacy in the West. Leading Christian theologians and thinkers will be studied.

title: Reformed Theology
description: Religious Studies : Selected topics illustrating the Reformers' theological agenda, with special reference to Luther, Zwingli and Calvin.

title: Religion and Globalization
description: Religious Studies : An exploration of the distinctive ways in which the world's religions are shaping and are shaped by the dynamics of globalization. It examines the multiple intersections of religion and globalization through a variety of themes and case studies in human rights, development, education, ecology, gender, and conflict

title: Conversations Across World Religions
description: Religious Studies : An intensive summer course that follows themes across the world's religions. Students will participate in conversations, lectures, and field visits related to a range of living faith traditions that are represented in Montreal and surrounding areas.
prerequesite: One 200 level RELG course and permission of the instructor.

title: Principles of Christian Theology 1
description: Religious Studies : An introduction to the central questions, claims, and categories of Christian thought, considered in their narrative and credal context, with discussion of the nature of theology and the relation between faith and reason.

title: Christian Thought and Culture
description: Religious Studies : Examines selected cultural and countercultural features of Christianity, with attention to theological anthropology and, for example, to political and legal philosophy, or social and bioethics, or the creative arts.
prerequesite: One prior course in Christianity, or permission of the instructor.

title: Contemporary Theological Issues
description: Religious Studies : A study of contemporary theological issues.  Topic varies by year.
prerequesite: 3 credits in Christianity or permission of instructor

title: Themes in Buddhist Studies
description: Religious Studies : A focused examination of major themes within a branch of Theravada, Mahayana or Vajrayana Buddhism. Emphasis will be placed on both the close study of primary texts (in translation) in historical context and the application of recent methods to fundamental Buddhist concepts, ritual practices and community institutions.
prerequesite: RELG 252 or RELG 253 or permission of instructor

title: Women and the Christian Tradition
description: Religious Studies : Survey of women's involvement in the Christian tradition. Topics include feminist interpretation of scripture, ideas of virginity, marriage and motherhood, mysticism, asceticisms, European witchhunts, contemporary women's liberation theories.

title: Gender & Sexuality in Buddhism
description: Religious Studies : Religious perspectives on the body, gender and sexual activity in Buddhist cultures.
prerequesite: RELG 252 or permission of the instructor

title: Religion and the Sciences
description: Religious Studies : Philosophies of science and of religion have created a more positive dialogue on questions of method, symbolism and rationality. Examines key issues (e.g. creation and evolution; objectivity and involvement; determinism and freedom) raised by natural and social sciences, and various possible solutions.

title: Introduction: Philosophy of Religion
description: Religious Studies : Introduction to the subject. Faith and reason, theistic arguments, values and destiny, the problem of evil, religious language.

title: Theravada Buddhist Literature
description: Religious Studies : The evolution of doctrines, practices and institutions explored through critical survey of Pali Canon (in translation), focusing on the dialogues of Gotama Buddha and his community during its first five centuries and on the historical accounts contained in the codes of monastic discipline.

title: Topics: Philosophy of Religion
description: Religious Studies : Selected topics in the philosophy of religion.  Topic varies by year.

title: Mahayana Buddhism
description: Religious Studies : Investigation of Mahayana schools of thought based on reading of key sutras and commentarial literature.

title: Religion and the Arts 1
description: Religious Studies : Topics of current interest in Religion and the Arts.

title: Topics in Religion and the Arts
description: Religious Studies : Topics in religion and the arts.

title: Classical Hinduism
description: Religious Studies : The study of classical Hindu values in historical context with reference to the goals and stages of life, traditional Hindu laws, ethics (including biomedical ethics), axiology and moral dilemmas in the Epics, gender differences, notions of orthodoxy, and the expansion of Hinduism.
prerequesite: RELG 252 or permission of the instructor

title: Bhakti Hinduism
description: Religious Studies : Foundation of theism in the Upanisads, Epics, Gita and puranas; image worship and temple religion in the Agamas; Vaisnavism, Saivism, Saktism, and competition with Buddhism and Jainism; the relation of Bhakti and Tantra; interaction of Hinduism, Islam, and Sikhism.
prerequesite: RELG 252 or permission of the instructor

title: Japanese Religions: History and Thought
description: Religious Studies : This course provides an in-depth introduction to the religious traditions of Japan from the emerging of the Japanese state to the role of religion in contemporary Japan. Kami worship, the Buddhist tradition, Yin Yang divination, Confucianism, and the modern construct of Shinto are addressed in an interdisciplinary approach, taking into account insights from the fields of History, Literature, and Art.

title: Gandhi: His Life and Thought
description: Religious Studies : A study of the life and thought of Gandhi.

title: Chinese Religions
description: Religious Studies : This course studies the Confucian classics, philosophical and religious Taoism, and Neo-Confucianism and also examines the syncresis between the Chinese religions and Indian Buddhism.

title: Religion and the Arts 2
description: Religious Studies : Topics of current interest in Religion and the Arts.

title: Gender & Sexuality in Hinduism
description: Religious Studies : Religious perspectives on the body, gender and sexual activity in Hindu cultures. Topics include: dharma and sexual practice; female sexuality; Bhakti and Tantra; same-sex relations; hijras; eroticism in the literary, visual, and performing arts; colonialism, Hindu nationalism, and the politics of gender.
prerequesite: RELG 252 or Permission of the instructor.

title: Sanskrit 2
description: Religious Studies : Advanced grammar and vocabulary with readings in epic and similar texts.
prerequesite: RELG 257 or permission of the instructor

title: Sanskrit 2
description: Religious Studies : See RELG 357D1 for course description.

title: Religion and Cinema in India
description: Religious Studies : The the aim of this course is to foreground discussions of performativity, visual culture, and representation in the study of modern South Asian religions. It focuses on a range of themes such as nationalism, devotion, secularism, and censorship. Course content will vary from year to year.
prerequesite: RELG 252 or permission of the instructor.

title: Religious Behaviour
description: Religious Studies : A study of the psychological origins of religion, of some aspects of the religious life (e.g. prayer, conversion, mystical experiences), and of some contemporary religious phenomena (e.g. marginal religious groups, the charismatic movement, glossolalia). The views of Freud and Jung are also considered.

title: Intermediate Tibetan 1
description: Religious Studies : Advanced Tibetan grammar, and translation of selected Tibetan texts.
prerequesite: RELG 265 or permission of the instructor.

title: Intermediate Tibetan 2
description: Religious Studies : Continuation of advanced Tibetan grammar and translation of selected Tibetan texts.
prerequesite: RELG 364 or permission of the instructor.

title: Rivers, Religion, and Environment in South Asia
description: Religious Studies : This class explores the significance of major South Asian river systems, including Ganges, Indus, Brahmaputra, and Yamuna, in classical and contemporary terms. In Hindu scriptures, rivers may be incarnate, emplaced goddesses; in contemporary South Asia, rivers are central to Hindu pilgrimage while facing environmental pressures from pollution, overuse, flooding, and drought. Finally, rivers of the Indian subcontinent cross and delineate international boundaries, creating friction between India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh. As key lifelines shared in multi-religious South Asia, are rivers vulnerable wards of the state—or valuable ‘citizens’ who must be recruited to do their part?

title: Tibetan Buddhism
description: Religious Studies : Buddhism has been central to Tibetan culture and identity since the 7th century CE. This course introduces key aspects of the history and practices of Tibetan Buddhism, including: early history, political and sectarian developments, the spread of Tibetan Buddhism outside of Tibet, and the myth of "Shangri-La".

title: Religion and Human Rights
description:
Religious Studies : Social justice and human rights issues as key aspects of modem religious ethics. Topics include: the relationship of religion to the modem human rights movement;
religious perspectives on the universality of human rights; the scope and limits of religious freedom; conflicts between religion and rights.

title: Ethics of Violence/Non-Violence
description: Religious Studies : Forms of violence and the reaction of religious groups are assessed both for their effectiveness and for their fidelity to their professed beliefs. Different traditions, ranging from the wholesale adoption of violent methods (e.g., the Crusades) to repudiation (e.g., Gandhi; the Peace Churches).

title: Hindu Goddesses
description: Religious Studies : The mythology, theology, soteriology, history, ritual, and texts of the goddess-centred (Sakta) branches of Hinduism.

title: Christian Ethics of Love
description: Religious Studies : This course will focus on the philosophical sources of love and on their uses by Christian authors. By comparing both their premises and methods, we will see how different authors in a particular tradition (Christianity) offer various answers to the themes of love, friendship and charity.

title: Topics: Philosophy of Religion
description: Religious Studies : Selected topics in the philosophy of religion.  Topic varies by year.

title: Religion, Politics and Society
description: Religious Studies : A study of contemporary religious traditions in the light of debates regarding secularization, the relation of religion and politics, and the interaction of religion with major social institutions.

title: Religious Ethics
description: Religious Studies : A discussion of ethical theory will provide the background for an analysis of the relationship between religious world views and moral reason. Attention will be given to the way in which the dominant religious traditions view the exemplars of religious virtue, and to how the virtues exemplified are related to and justified by the faith tradition in which they operate.

title: Religious Controversies
description: Religious Studies : A comparative survey of types and topics of argumentation developed in the literature of controversy. Texts discussed include disputations, missionary sermons and polemical treatises.

title: Pilgrimage and Religious Tourism in South Asia
description: Religious Studies : An exploration of the relationship of pilgrimage and tourism in contemporary South Asia. Beginning with the classical foundations of Hindu pilgrimage in Indic civilization, the coursework puts pilgrimage in South Asia in critical perspective by exploring new motivations for religious travel in Hindu, Muslim, Sikh and Buddhist contexts.

title: Eastern Orthodox Christianity
description: Religious Studies : Topics in the history, theology, spiritual practices, liturgical arts, and literatures of the Greek, Slavonic, Syriac, Coptic, Armenian, and related Christian traditions.

title: Religion, Philosophy, Modernity
description: Religious Studies : Through primary source readings, this class will examine the intellectual history of this change, will identify the agents of this change, both philosophical and theological, and will consider the significance and implications of inhabiting a 'modernity' that is, and understands itself as, 'secular.' Charles Taylor's recent book, A Secular Age, narrates a historical development, from a 'pre-modern' condition, in which it was 'virtually impossible not to believe in and encounter God,' to a modern and contemporary situation in which 'faith is an embattled option.' Within the 'context of our self-understanding,' 'secularism' has become a 'default option.'

title: Advanced New Testament Greek
description: Religious Studies : A review of grammar and syntax with an emphasis on rapid reading of sections chosen from different parts of the New Testament.
prerequesite: RELG 280 or equivalent, with a minimum grade of 70%

title: Introduction to Jainism
description: Religious Studies : This course provides an introduction to Jaina religious culture, including elements of its history, philosophy, cosmology, and monastic and lay practices. It also focuses on constructions of Jainismâ•Žs precept of universal non-violence (ahimsa), and addresses Jaina responses to contemporary social and ethical issues.

title: Introduction to Sikhism
description: Religious Studies : An introduction to the historical and religious context in which the Sikh religion developed, its principal doctrines, practices and institutions and its evolution from its origins to the present, both inside and outside India.
prerequesite: RELG 252 or the permission of the instructor.

title: Elementary Biblical Hebrew
description: Religious Studies : An introduction to the grammar and syntax of Biblical Hebrew. Emphasis is placed on both the oral and the written language.

title: Elementary Biblical Hebrew
description: Religious Studies : An introduction to the grammar and syntax of Biblical Hebrew. Emphasis is placed on both the oral and the written language.

title: Elementary Biblical Hebrew
description: Religious Studies : See RELG 390D1 for course description.

title: Christian Spirituality
description: Religious Studies : Seminar exploring the phenomena of internal religious experience in their relation to received formularies of Christian thought and practice.

title: The Writings
description: Religious Studies : A study of Job with some attention to Proverbs and Ecclesiastes (in English translation).
prerequesite: RELG 202, or RELG 302 and RELG 303, or equivalent

title: The Prophets
description: Religious Studies : A study of significant texts selected from the prophetic tradition in the Old Testament.

title: New Testament Exegesis
description: Religious Studies : A seminar in exegesis on the basis of representative passages chosen from different parts of the New Testament in English.

title: Canadian Church History
description: Religious Studies : A survey of the major Christian traditions in Canada from the settlement of New France to the present. Lectures and seminars with use, where possible, of primary source materials.
prerequesite: RELG 323 or HIST 202 or HIST 203 or HIST 357 or CANS 202

title: Reformation Thought
description: Religious Studies : An examination of issues and persons in Europe and the British Isles that contributed to ecclesiastical and social change during the 16th and early 17th centuries.

title: Principles of Christian Theology 2
description: Religious Studies : This course is normally pursuant to RELG 333. It examines in more depth methodological issues as well as particular themes in theology, christology, soteriology, ecclesiology, and eschatology, through readings in major theologians.
prerequesite: RELG 333 or permission of the instructor.

title: Religious Dialogues
description: Religious Studies : A comparative survey of the literature of Western religious dialogues, addressing the history and diversity of debates concerning religion. Texts to be discussed include dialogues by Plato, Cicero, Augustine, Boethius, Anselm, Cusanus, Leo Hebraeus, Erasmus, Thomas More, Jean Bodin, Leibniz and Hume.

title: Global Islam
description: Religious Studies : Western scholarship has oscillated between orientalizing Islam and co-opting it into the Western (Abrahamic) fold of religious traditions. The course will challenge both perspectives by exploring Islam’s dynamic unfolding across a variety of civilizational regions and during subsequent epochs. Its patterns of premodern globalization are nowadays retrieved, sometimes by fitting Islamic cultures into neoliberal patterns of globalization, more often by sidelining or overlaying the Westphalian system of sovereign nation-states. The course will show how Islamic traditions have, both in history and in the present, developed unique intellectual tools and practical resources to interface both with ‘radical’ (Abrahamic) and ‘dialogic’ (non-Abrahamic) religious traditions: from the West (also via labor-based migration), through Central and South Asia, to East and Southeast Asia.

title: Phenomenology of Religion
description: Religious Studies : A study of the phenomenology of religion.
prerequesite: RELG 341 or permission of the instructor.

title: Pure Land Buddhism
description: Religious Studies : The concept of Buddha Countries and Pure Lands in Buddhism, the Western Pure Land of Amida (Jodokyo) and its basic scriptures, the Chinese Buddhist schools, the introduction to Japan and the foundation of the Pure Land school by Honen, the Pure Land School of Shinran and its development, and the other Pure Land related schools.
prerequesite: RELG 252 and RELG 253, or RELG 342 or RELG 344, or permission of instructor

title: Japanese Esoteric Buddhism
description: Religious Studies : The development of esoteric Buddhism in India and Tibet; its Chinese formation and introduction to Japan; Kukai, Shingonshu and Tendai esotericism; the Tachikawa traditions of sexual esotericism; Mandal, iconography and liturgy.
prerequesite: RELG 252 and RELG 253, or RELG 342, or RELG 344

title: Indian Ocean Religious Networks
description: Religious Studies : This seminar class explores cultural exchanges among maritime networks of Hindus, Buddhists, and Muslims in South Asia and Southeast Asia, in classical, pre-modern, and contemporary terms. Key themes to be considered include: sovereignty, society, and religion, within the context of historically evolving cultural relations around the Bay of Bengal. Taking an inter-religious approach to understanding maritime cultural interactions, class readings and discussion include: foundational theories of “Indianization,” reflection on “localization,” the “Sanskrit cosmpolis,” and emerging theoretical contributions based on current archaeological, epigraphic, and art historical discoveries in India, Malaysia, Singapore, and Indonesia. Deptl. approval: Nov.17, 2015.

title: Zen: Maxims and Methods
description: Religious Studies : Through the reading of such key Zen writings as The Platform Sutra and selections from Zen Masters Chinul of Korea and Dôgen of Japan, an attempt will be made to relate Zen anecdote to meditational practice.
prerequesite: RELG 252, RELG 342 or RELG 344, or permission of instructor

title: East Asian Buddhism
description: Religious Studies : A study of East Asian Buddhism.

title: Vajrayana Buddhism
description: Religious Studies : A study of the history, philosophy and practices of Vajrayana Buddhism.

title: Modern Hindu Thought
description: Religious Studies : A study of the developments in religious thought with special reference to such thinkers as Ram Mohan Roy, Dayananda Saraswati, Ramakrishna, Vivekananda, Gandhi, Tilak, Aurobindo, and Radhakrishnan.

title: Religion and the Performing Arts in South India
description: Religious Studies : This course focuses on the place of religion in historical representations and performance practices of "classical" South Indian performing arts such as Bharatanatyam dance and Karnatak music. In particular, it lays emphasis on politics of the twentieth-century reinvention of these arts by elites in the Tamil and Telugu-speaking regions.

title: Theories of Religion
description: Religious Studies : The history of the academic study of religion from its beginnings in the 19th century until the present. Key texts by figures such as Max Muller, Sigmund Freud, Emile Durkheim, Max Weber, Mircea Eliade, Claude Levi-Strauss and Clifford Geertz will be studied.

title: Advanced Sanskrit
description: Religious Studies : Critical reading of selected Sanskrit texts.

title: Advanced Sanskrit
description: Religious Studies : See RELG 457D1 for course description.

title: Advanced Tibetan 1
description: Religious Studies : Translation of specially selected Tibetan texts.

title: Advanced Tibetan 2
description: Religious Studies : Continuation of translation of specially selected Tibetan texts.
prerequesite: RELG 464 or permission of the instructor.

title: Theological Ethics
description: Religious Studies : Examines ancient and modern sources of Christian moral thought against a backdrop of contemporary alternatives.
prerequesite: One course in theology or Christian thought and one course in philosophy or ethics.

title: Christian Social Ethics
description: Religious Studies

title: Christianity in Global Perspective
description: Religious Studies : Examines varied expressions of Christianity as a global religion with a particular focus on Asia, Africa and Latin America from the 18th century to the present.
prerequesite: A 300 level course in Christianity or permission of the Instructor.

title: Exegesis of Greek New Testament
description: Religious Studies : An intensive seminar in exegesis on the basis of representative passages chosen from different parts of the New Testament.
prerequesite: RELG 381 or equivalent, and RELG 311, RELG 312

title: Hebrew Texts
description: Religious Studies : Translation and exegesis of selected texts.

title: Hebrew Texts
description: Religious Studies : Translation and exegesis of selected texts.

title: B.Th. Honours Seminar 1
description: Religious Studies : Open to students in the final year of B.Th. Honours. Provides opportunity for advanced development of research interests and methods in the student's area of Honours specialization.
prerequesite: permission of the Chair of the B.Th. Committee

title: B.Th. Honours Seminar 2
description: Religious Studies : Open to students in the final year of B.Th. Honours. Provides further opportunity for advanced development of research interests and methods in the student's area of Honours specialization.
prerequesite: RELG 494 and permission of the Chair of the B.Th. Committee

title: Special Studies
description: Religious Studies : Special studies in Religious Studies.  Topic varies by year.

title: Research Seminar
description: Religious Studies : Research seminar in Religious Studies.  Topic varies by year.

title: Special Studies
description: Religious Studies : Special studies in Religious Studies.  Topic varies by year.
prerequesite: permission of the Chair of the B.Th. Committee

title: Internship: Religious Studies
description: Religious Studies : Internship with an approved host institution or organization.
prerequesite: permission of the Chair of the B.Th. Committee

title: Greco-Roman Judaism
description: Religious Studies : The religion and literature of wisdom and apocalyptic traditions, the Dead Sea Scrolls, Philo and Josephus, with special attention to the Jewish matrix of Early Christianity.

title: History of Christian Thought 1
description: Religious Studies : The development of Christian theology in the Patristic and Medieval periods. Focus on the controversial development of Christian doctrines and disciplines through intensive exposure to primary texts.
prerequesite: At least six (6) credits at the 300 level in Christianity or the Christian Bible.

title: History of Christian Thought 2
description: Religious Studies : The development of Christian theology in the Reformation, Post Reformation and Modern periods through intensive exposure to primary texts.
prerequesite: At least six (6) credits at the 300 level in Christianity or the Christian Bible.

title: Ethnography as Method in Religious Studies
description: Religious Studies : Ethnography as method informs disciplines from Area Studies and anthropology to linguistics and religious studies. Students will acquire a critical perspective on emic/etic subjectivity in Religious Studies, and a framework to apply ethnography in their research. Coursework covers classic ethnographies, new interventions, and ethnographies of particular relevance for religious traditions in a given year.
prerequesite: A minimum of six credits in 300 level RELG courses and/or permission of the instructor.

title: Ramayana: Multiple Lives
description: Religious Studies : Focus on the Rama story in South Asia. Exploration of the multiple versions of the narrative from classical Sanskrit textual versions, to rural vernacular retellings, to contemporary TV versions, and examination of the various religious, social, cultural and political significations of the narrative in these contexts.

title: Indian Philosophy
description: Religious Studies : Introduction to the orthodox systems of Hindu Philosophy leading up to Vedanta i.e., Nyaya, Vaisesika, Sankhya, Yoga and Mimamsa, which will include discussion of such topics as: grounds for belief and disbelief in God, the nature of revelation, means of knowledge, etc.
prerequesite: 6 credits in Indian religions, philosophy of religion, philosophy, or permission of the instructor

title: Special Topics in Hinduism
description: Religious Studies : A research-oriented seminar dealing with topics in Hindu studies.
prerequesite: 6 credits in Indian religions, philosophy of religion, philosophy, or permission of the instructor

title: Indian Buddhist Philosophy
description: Religious Studies : The rise of buddhist schools of philosophy, especially the Theravada and Sauntrantika, as an attempt to systematize the canonical teachings and defend Buddhism against its critics.
prerequesite: RELG 252 or RELG 342 or permission of instructor

title: Japanese Buddhism in Historical Context
description: Religious Studies : This research-oriented seminar critically analyses key-questions from the field of pre-modern Japanese Buddhism. By engaging with recent research, students are expected to adopt an interdisciplinary approach and address questions and methodologies from both History and Buddhist Studies.
prerequesite: RELG 344, or  RELG 451, or permission of the instructor.

title: Special Topics in Buddhism
description: Religious Studies : A research-oriented seminar dealing with topics in Buddhist studies.

title: Advaita Vedanta
description: Religious Studies : The relation of Nyaya-Vaisesika and Mimamsa to Kevaladvaita with concentration on Sankara's Brahmasutrabhasya, Pada 1 and 2.

title: Religions of South India 1
description: Religious Studies : Topics include: definitions of Tamil identity, the relation of akam to bhakti poetry, the theology of the Alvars and Nayanmars, inter-religious and sectarian competition, the motif of pilgrimage, questions of caste and women.

title: Religions of South Asia
description: Religious Studies : This course familiarises students with major issues in the interpretation of South Asian religions with concern for historical-, regional-, and socio-political studies. Students will become conversant with the work of key contributors in the study of South Asian religions in terms of methodologies, major works, and the reception and audience of their writings.
prerequesite: 6 credits in Asian religions or permission of the instructor.

title: Honours Seminar
description: Religious Studies : Current trends in the study of religion, including the approaches of critical theory, feminism, post-modernism, and post-colonialism.

title: Issues in Buddhist Studies
description: Religious Studies : A graduate seminar taught by the Numata Visiting Professor on critical issues in contemporary Buddhist Studies. Emphasis will be placed on the intensive application of different methods - philological, philosophical or social scientific - to some area of modern Buddhist research.

title: Indian Tantric Traditions
description: Religious Studies : Study of esoteric Tantric culture (philosophy, ritual, pilgrimage, art, and iconography) with focus on either Hindu or Buddhist Tantric traditions.
prerequesite: Any two 300-level courses in Hinduism or Buddhism.

title: Caste and Dalits: Historical and Political Perspectives
description: Religious Studies : This seminar addresses religion, caste, and the Dalit community (formerly known as "untouchables" in India through a range of historical and ritual contexts. Topics include representation in the Hindu textual tradition, colonialism, conversion, caste-based violence, caste and nationalism, non-Brahmin political assertion, and the contemporary reservation system.
prerequesite: RELG 252 and one 300 level course or higher in South Asian Religions

title: Buddhist Poetry
description: Religious Studies : Since the time of Buddha, poetry has been used by Buddhist to express devotion, to compose philosophical treatises, and to communicate insight into the experience of awakening. The seminar's content will vary, treating the history, poetics, esthetics, roles and genres of Buddhist poetry in India, Tibet, China and Japan.
prerequesite: RELG 252 or RELG 253 or RELG 344 or permission of the instructor

title: Ethics, Medicine and Religion
description: Religious Studies : The seminar will discuss a variety of topics related to medicine and religion from the point of view of ethics, such as the pact of care between a patient and  a physician, the Hippocratic oath, the notions of autonomy and vulnerability, the definitions of personhood and human dignity, the question of rights for people with cognitive disabilities, the debate about the role of religion in bioethics.

title: Religion and Global Politics
description: Religious Studies : An exploration of the resurgence of global religions in geo-political and international relations in the post Cold-War era. It examines the complex roles that religious traditions play in democratization, human rights, conflict, and development.

title: Religions in Global Society
description: Religious Studies : This seminar is devoted to the study of a plurality of often intersecting religious traditions in a globalizing world, based on interdisciplinary scholarship drawing from history, sociology, anthropology and archaeology. It starts from locating religious phenomena within intersecting social, cultural and political fabrics around the world. It articulates the relation between a multi-faith appreciation of the role of religions in a variety of societies and the emergence of diverse patterns of secularity in them. It facilitates a rich understanding of a complex past to shed light on the new challenges of globalization, including the opening of horizons of postsecular understandings and arrangements.
prerequesite: RELG 208 or RELG 331 or permission of instructor

title: Topics in Christian Liturgy and Music
description: Religious Studies : Topics in the history and practice of liturgy and church music with attention to hymnody, principles of liturgical change, interrelation of music and liturgy, and interpretations of scripture and theologies within church music, with relation to particular periods and settings in the history of Christianity.
prerequesite: One 300-level MUHL course or RELG 322 or RELG 323 or permission of the instructor

title: Hellenistic Religious Texts
description: Religious Studies : Translation and discussion of Hellenistic Greek texts pertaining to the study of topics in Early Christianity and Greco-Roman religions.
prerequesite: RELG 482 or permission of the instructor.

title: Ancient Jewish Literature
description: Religious Studies : An examination of current theories of the origin and development of Greco-Roman Judaism with special attention to the treatment of non-canonical Jewish writings, e.g., the Pseudopigrapha and the Qumran Scrolls.

title: Theory in Religious Ethics
description: Religious Studies : Basic theories in philosophical and religious ethics.

title: Interpreters of Religion and Faith of Ancient Israel
description: Religious Studies : A study of how the biblical tradition has been analyzed and evaluated by outstanding scholars.

title: Pauline Theology
description: Religious Studies : A study of the nature, background, origins, development and expression of the theological ideas in the Pauline literature and the connection between these ideas and other early Christian thought.

title: The Ministry of Jesus
description: Religious Studies : A study of the Synoptic Presentation of the Aims, Teaching and Achievement of Jesus of Nazareth.

title: The Church in the New Testament
description: Religious Studies : A study of the history of the Early Church on the basis of the New Testament Writings.

title: Patristic Studies
description: Religious Studies : Selected texts of patristic theology and history of the early Christian Church from Irenaeus to Boethius.

title: Medieval Studies
description: Religious Studies : Selected religious and theological texts from Boethius to Nicholas of Cusa.

title: Reformation Studies
description: Religious Studies : Selected texts of Reformation and Counter-Reformation theology and history.

title: Creeds and Confessions
description: Religious Studies : An examination of selected credal and confessional statements from earliest extant confessional expressions to twentieth century creeds.

title: Reformation: Secular Dimensions
description: Religious Studies : A study of major contributions to political theology from the late fifteenth to the mid-seventeenth centuries. This course will examine Reformation discourse on law and civil power and will aim to interpret the development of secularity in this period.

title: Primary Text: Aramaic
description: Religious Studies : Religious texts in Aramaic, with particular attention to the problems of translation and interpretation as they apply to the student's thesis research.
prerequesite: Basic reading knowledge of Aramaic or permission of instructor

title: Theological Foundations
description: Religious Studies : Readings and discussions of theologians from the formative periods of Christian thought, with attention to the history of philosophy, ethics and dogma.

title: The Theology of Karl Barth
description: Religious Studies : Extensive reading and discussion of Part IV of the Church Dogmatics with special reference to Barth's Christology, doctrine of sin, ecclesiology, eschatology and doctrine of Christian life.

title: Christology and Ecclesiology
description: Religious Studies : Studies in the relation between two central theological loci, with special attention to their trinitarian, sacramental and eschatological frame of reference.

title: Primary Text: Biblical Hebrew
description: Religious Studies : Religious texts in Biblical Hebrew, with particular attention to the problems of translation and interpretation as they relate to the student's thesis research.
prerequesite: Basic reading knowledge of Biblical Hebrew or permission of instructor.

title: Modern Philosophy of Religion
description: Religious Studies : Review of modern philosophy of religion.

title: Philosophy of Religion in the 21st Century
description: Religious Studies : The course is dedicated to the examination of selected contemporary authors in the field of philosophy of religion.

title: Problems: Philosophy of Religion
description: Religious Studies : Faith and skepticism.

title: Biblical Theology
description: Religious Studies : Tutorials and guided reading in the field of biblical theology.

title: Methods in Religious Studies
description: Religious Studies : Theoretical and methodological approaches to the study of religion, including: historical studies/textual hermeneutics; ritual/performance studies; and religion and modernity.

title: Research Project 1
description: Religious Studies : An analysis of the research approaches of certain designated interdisciplinary fields of study. These independent studies are structured to provide students with the necessary research skills in their adopted interdisciplinary studies and will be presented in the form of a project to be determined by the student and Area studies professor.

title: Research Project 2
description: Religious Studies : An analysis of the research approaches of certain designated interdisciplinary fields of study. These independent studies are structured to provide students with the necessary research skills in their adopted interdisciplinary studies and will be presented in the form of a project to be determined by the student and Area studies professor.

title: Church History
description: Religious Studies : Tutorials and guided reading in the field of church history.

title: Primary Text: Coptic
description: Religious Studies : Religious texts in Coptic, with particular attention to the problems of translation and interpretation as they apply to the student's thesis research.
prerequesite: RELG 280 or equivalent; Basic reading knowledge of Coptic or permission of instructor

title: Christian Theology
description: Religious Studies : Tutorials and guided reading in the field of Christian theology.

title: Philosophy of Religion
description: Religious Studies : Tutorials and guided reading in the field of philosophy of religion.

title: Theological Ethics
description: Religious Studies : Tutorials and guided reading in the field of theological ethics.

title: Introductory Sanskrit
description: Religious Studies : To develop advanced basic language and reading skills.

title: Introductory Sanskrit
description: Religious Studies : See RELG 657D1 for course description.

title: Dogen: Philosophy and Practice
description: Religious Studies : An introduction to the recent scholarship on the Japanese Zen monk Dogen focussing on both his philosophical writings and his attempt to create a life of monastic practice.
prerequesite: RELG 451 or permission of the instructor.

title: M.A. Research Paper 1
description: Religious Studies : The writing of the research paper.

title: M.A. Research Paper 2
description: Religious Studies : The writing of the research paper.

title: M.A. Research Paper 3
description: Religious Studies : The writing of the research paper.

title: Comparative Religion
description: Religious Studies : Tutorials and guided reading in the field of comparative religion.

title: Primary Text: Sanskrit 1
description: Religious Studies : The Sanskrit alphabet, basic morphology and syntax of the classical language. Reading and analysis of passages from the Hindu epics and fable literature.
prerequesite: Basic reading knowledge of Sanskrit or permission of instructor

title: Primary Text: Sanskrit 2
description: Religious Studies : Focus on development of greater speed and accuracy in reading poetry, mythology and philosophical texts, basic grammar, an introduction to the Sanskrit grammarians, analysis of word formation and compound formation, and to the conventions of commentators.
prerequesite: Basic reading knowledge of Sanskrit or RELG 665 or permission of instructor

title: Readings in Indic Texts 1
description: Religious Studies : Advanced course in critical reading of Sanskrit and/or other Indian texts.
prerequesite: RELG 457D1/D2 or equivalent or permission of instructor.

title: Readings in Indic Texts 2
description: Religious Studies : Continued critical reading of Sanskrit and/or other Indian texts.
prerequesite: RELG 457D1/D2 or equivalent or permission of instructor.

title: Primary Text: Tibetan
description: Religious Studies : Comparison of original Sanskrit texts with their Tibetan translations. For advanced students of Sanskrit who wish to learn to consult Tibetan translations of Buddhist texts originally written in Sanskrit.
prerequesite: RELG 357 or permission of the instructor

title: Research in Interfaith Studies
description: Religious Studies : This seminar takes full measure of the complex entanglements of religious and cultural traditions in history and the present. It explores the interaction of diverse yet intersecting universes of practice and meaning originating from notions of transcendence but embracing various spheres of human and social activities, from the arts through trade to healing. It pays particular attention to the relational and networked nature of religious formation and its contestability and reformability across a diverse spectrum of life-orientational commitments and disciplines of the body.

title: Old Testament Research
description: Religious Studies : A survey of research in the Old Testament.

title: Research in New Testament
description: Religious Studies : A survey of research in the New Testament.

title: Research: History of Christianity
description: Religious Studies : A survey of research in the history of Christianity.

title: Research in Christian Theology
description: Religious Studies : Theologies of Religious Pluralism.

title: Research in Philosophy of Religion 1
description: Religious Studies : A survey of research in the philosophy of religion.

title: Research in Ethical Problems
description: Religious Studies : A survey of research in ethical problems.

title: Research in Comparative Religion 1
description: Religious Studies : A survey of research in comparative religion.

title: Thesis Research 1
description: Religious Studies : Independent research work under the direction of the Thesis Supervisor and the Supervisory Committee.

title: Thesis Research 2
description: Religious Studies : Independent research work under the direction of the Thesis Supervisor and the Supervisory Committee.

title: Old Testament Research
description: Religious Studies : A survey of research in the Old Testament.

title: Research: History of Christianity
description: Religious Studies : A survey of research in the history of Christianity.

title: Research in Christian Theology
description: Religious Studies : Theologies of Religious Pluralism.

title: Research in Philosophy of Religion 2
description: Religious Studies : A survey of research in the philosophy of religion.

title: Research in Ethical Problems
description: Religious Studies : A survey of research in ethical problems.

title: Thesis Research 3
description: Religious Studies : Independent research work under the direction of the Thesis Supervisor and the Supervisory Committee.

title: Thesis Research 4
description: Religious Studies : Independent research work under the direction of the Thesis Supervisor and the Supervisory Committee.

title: Major Comprehensive Examination
description: Religious Studies : The Major Comprehensive Examination tests whether the doctoral student has the professional scholar's grasp of the entire field of specialization.

title: Minor Comprehensive Examination
description: Religious Studies : The Minor Comprehensive Examination tests the doctoral student's knowledge and understanding of a secondary field which is cognate or comparative to the field of specialization.

title: Oral Comprehensive Examination
description: Religious Studies : The Oral Comprehensive Examination clarifies and supplements the written comprehensive examination(s).

title: Meaning and Interpretation
description: Religious Studies : An interdisciplinary seminar on hermeneutical problems.

title: Tutorial on a Selected Topic
description: Religious Studies : Individualized guided research on an approved topic.

title: Elementary Russian Language 1
description: Russian (Arts) : Reading, grammar, translation, oral practice.

title: Elementary Russian Language 2
description: Russian (Arts) : Russian Language; continuation of RUSS 210.

title: Introduction to Soviet Film
description: Russian (Arts) : This course aims to familiarize undergraduates with the topics, figures, and concerns of Soviet film history. Students will watch and analyze films by Soviet directors including Sergei Eisenstein, Dziga Vertov, Andrei Tarkovsky, Sergei Parajanov, Kira Muratova, Larisa Shepitko, and many others in the context of their historical periods, movements, and writings. Students will learn to analyze images and cinematic techniques, as well as assess their historical, ideological, and cultural significance.

title: Elementary Russian Language Intensive 1
description: Russian (Arts) : An intensive introduction to the Russian language which covers the first year of the normal level, i.e. RUSS 210/RUSS 211 in one semester. The basic grammatical structures are covered.

title: Russia's Eternal Questions
description: Russian (Arts) : Exploration of cultural archetypes defining continuity and change from Peter the Great to the present; the Russian national identity, double-faith, Western and Slovophile influences, Mother Russia, superfluous men and the Eternal Feminine, anarchism, the avant-garde, Stalinism. Recurring themes traced in literature, art, film, music, pop culture and the applied arts.

title: Russian Literature and Revolution
description: Russian (Arts) : The dramatic developments in Russian literature of the 20th century, from revolution, through conformity, to the ironies and anxieties of the post-Soviet era. Comrades, iconoclasts, absurdists, proletarians and aesthetes; the Gulag, the literary café, the music of the spheres, the crumbling Russian village; the reforging of humanity and the rediscovery of tradition.
prerequesite: None, but some background in Russian 20C history is helpful

title: Russian 19th Century: Literary Giants 1
description: Russian (Arts) : The Golden Age of Russian literature: from Pushkin, Lermontov, and Gogol to the first works of Dostoevsky and Tolstoy. This course traces the rise of a coherent literary tradition in Russia, exploring authors’ relationships to the burgeoning tradition and to their historical and cultural context.

title: Russian 19th Century: Literary Giants 2
description: Russian (Arts) : This course explores the masterpieces of late nineteenth-century Russian literature. From psychological realism and the novel of ideas to the rise of the great short story; Turgenev, Dostoevsky, Tolstoy, Leskov, and Chekhov.

title: Introduction to Russian Folklore
description: Russian (Arts) : An introduction to Russian folklore and folk belief: "dual-faith," traditional mentality, fairy tales, calendar rituals, folk songs, witches, healers and house spirits.  The course will explore classic approaches to folklore studies as well as the influence of folk culture on Russian "high art."

title: Russian for Heritage Speakers 1
description: Russian (Arts) : For native speakers of Russian who have not had full academic instruction in the language. Focus on grammatical structure and syntax, the formalities of written Russian and appreciation of the language's stylistic diversity. Multi- media approach including excerpts from literary works, current newspapers, television news broadcasts, films and cartoons.

title: Russian for Heritage Speakers 2
description: Russian (Arts) : For native speakers of Russian who have not had full academic instruction in the language. Focus on complex grammatical structures, syntax, and stylistically differentiated uses of vocabulary in written and spoken Russian.  Multi-media approach including excerpts from literary works, current newspapers, Internet sources, and films.
prerequesite: RUSS 300 or permission of the instructor

title: Intermediate Russian Language 1
description: Russian (Arts) : Reading, translation, conversation.

title: Intermediate Russian Language 2
description: Russian (Arts) : Reading, translation, conversation.

title: Intermediate Russian Language Intensive 2
description: Russian (Arts) : Continuing the Intensive program of RUSS 215 this course covers the second year of the normal level, i.e. RUSS 310/RUSS 311, in one semester. The basic grammatical structures are covered.

title: Reading Russian Poetry
